  32class SNES_Poisson(SNES_Scalar):
  33    r"""
  34    This class provides functionality for a discrete representation
  35    of the Poisson equation
  36
  37    $$
  38    \nabla \cdot
  39            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla u \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} =
  40            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ f \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}}
  41    $$
  42
  43    The term $\mathbf{F}$ relates the flux to gradients in the unknown $u$
  44
  45    ## Properties
  46
  47      - The unknown is $u$
  48
  49      - The diffusivity tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the `constitutive_model` property to
  50    one of the scalar `uw.constitutive_models` classes and populating the parameters.
  51    It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear
  52    or anisotropic.
  53
  54      - $f$ is a volumetric source term
  55    """
  56
  57    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
  58    def __init__(
  59        self,
  60        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
  61        u_Field: uw.discretisation.MeshVariable = None,
  62        solver_name: str = "",
  63        verbose=False,
  64        degree=2,
  65    ):
  66        ## Keep track
  67
  68        ## Parent class will set up default values etc
  69        super().__init__(
  70            mesh,
  71            u_Field,
  72            None,
  73            None,
  74            degree,
  75            solver_name,
  76            verbose,
  77        )
  78
  79        if solver_name == "":
  80            solver_name = "Poisson_{}_".format(self.instance_number)
  81
  82        # Register the problem setup function
  83        self._setup_problem_description = self.poisson_problem_description
  84
  85        # default values for properties
  86        self.f = sympy.Matrix.zeros(1, 1)
  87
  88        self._constitutive_model = None
  89
  90    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
  91    def poisson_problem_description(self):
  92        # f1 residual term (weighted integration) - scalar function
  93        self._f0 = self.F0 - self.f
  94
  95        # f1 residual term (integration by parts / gradients)
  96        # isotropic
  97        self._f1 = self.F1 + self.constitutive_model.flux.T
  98
  99        return
 100
 101    @property
 102    def f(self):
 103        return self._f
 104
 105    @f.setter
 106    def f(self, value):
 107        self.is_setup = False
 108        self._f = sympy.Matrix((value,))
 109
 110    @property
 111    def CM_is_setup(self):
 112        return self._constitutive_model._solver_is_setup

 115class SNES_Darcy(SNES_Scalar):
 116    r"""
 117    This class provides functionality for a discrete representation
 118    of the Groundwater flow equations
 119
 120    $$
 121    \color{Green}{\underbrace{ \Bigl[  S_s \frac{\partial h}{\partial t} \Bigr]}_{\dot{\mathbf{f}}}} -
 122    \nabla \cdot
 123            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla h  - \boldsymbol{s}\Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} =
 124            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ W \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}}
 125    $$
 126
 127    The flux term, $\mathbf{F}$ relates the effective velocity to pressure gradients
 128
 129    $$
 130    \boldsymbol{v} = \left( \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla h  - \boldsymbol{s} \right)
 131    $$
 132
 133    The time-dependent term $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ is not implemented in this version.
 134
 135    ## Properties
 136
 137      - The unknown is $h$, the hydraulic head
 138
 139      - The permeability tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the `constitutive_model` property to
 140    one of the scalar `uw.constitutive_models` classes and populating the parameters.
 141    It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear
 142    or anisotropic.
 143
 144      - Volumetric sources for the pressure gradient are supplied through
 145        the $s$ property [e.g. $s = \rho g$ ]
 146
 147      - $W$ is a pressure source term
 148
 149      - $S_s$ is the specific storage coefficient
 150
 151    ## Notes
 152
 153      - The solver returns the primary field and also the Darcy flux term (the mean-flow velocity)
 154
 155    """
 156
 157    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
 158    def __init__(
 159        self,
 160        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
 161        h_Field: Optional[uw.discretisation.MeshVariable] = None,
 162        v_Field: Optional[uw.discretisation.MeshVariable] = None,
 163        degree: int = 2,
 164        solver_name: str = "",
 165        verbose=False,
 166    ):
 167        ## Parent class will set up default values etc
 168        super().__init__(
 169            mesh,
 170            h_Field,
 171            None,  # DuDt
 172            None,  # DFDt
 173            degree,
 174            solver_name,
 175            verbose,
 176        )
 177
 178        if solver_name == "":
 179            self.solver_name = "Darcy_{}_".format(self.instance_number)
 180
 181        # Register the problem setup function
 182        self._setup_problem_description = self.darcy_problem_description
 183
 184        # default values for properties
 185        self._f = sympy.Matrix([[0]])
 186        self._k = 1
 187
 188        self._s = sympy.Matrix.zeros(rows=1, cols=self.mesh.dim)
 189        self._s[1] = -1
 190
 191        self._constitutive_model = None
 192
 193        ## Set up the projection operator that
 194        ## solves the flow rate
 195
 196        self._v_projector = uw.systems.solvers.SNES_Vector_Projection(
 197            self.mesh,
 198            v_Field,
 199            degree=self.Unknowns.u.degree - 1,
 200        )
 201
 202        self._v = self._v_projector.Unknowns.u
 203
 204        # If we add smoothing, it should be small relative to actual diffusion (self.viscosity)
 205        self._v_projector.smoothing = 0
 206
 207    ## This function is the one we will typically over-ride to build specific solvers.
 208    ## This example is a poisson-like problem with isotropic coefficients
 209
 210    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
 211    def darcy_problem_description(self):
 212        # f1 residual term (weighted integration)
 213        self._f0 = self.F0 - self.f
 214
 215        # f1 residual term (integration by parts / gradients)
 216        self._f1 = self.F1 + self.darcy_flux
 217
 218        # Flow calculation
 219        self._v_projector.uw_function = -self.darcy_flux
 220
 221        return
 222
 223    @property
 224    def f(self):
 225        return self._f
 226
 227    @f.setter
 228    def f(self, value):
 229        self.is_setup = False
 230        self._f = sympy.Matrix((value,))
 231
 232    #  ### W term not set up ???
 233    #  @property
 234    #  def W(self):
 235    #      return self._W
 236
 237    #  @W.setter
 238    #  def W(self, value):
 239    #      self.is_setup = False
 240    #      self._W = sympy.Matrix((value,))
 241
 242    @property
 243    def s(self):
 244        return self._s
 245
 246    @s.setter
 247    def s(self, value):
 248        self.is_setup = False
 249        self._s = sympy.Matrix((value,))
 250
 251    @property
 252    def darcy_flux(self):
 253        flux = self.constitutive_model.flux.T
 254        return flux
 255
 256    @property
 257    def v(self):
 258        return self._v
 259
 260    @v.setter
 261    def v(self, value):
 262        self._v_projector.is_setup = False
 263        self._v = sympify(value)
 264
 265    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
 266    def solve(
 267        self,
 268        zero_init_guess: bool = True,
 269        timestep: float = None,
 270        verbose: bool = False,
 271        _force_setup: bool = False,
 272    ):
 273        """
 274        Generates solution to constructed system.
 275
 276        Params
 277        ------
 278        zero_init_guess:
 279            If `True`, a zero initial guess will be used for the
 280            system solution. Otherwise, the current values of `self.u` will be used.
 281        timestep:
 282            value used to evaluate inertial contribution
 283        """
 284
 285        if (not self.is_setup) or _force_setup:
 286            self._setup_pointwise_functions(verbose)
 287            self._setup_discretisation(verbose)
 288            self._setup_solver(verbose)
 289
 290        # Solve pressure
 291
 292        super().solve(zero_init_guess, _force_setup)
 293
 294        # Now solve flow field
 295
 296        self._v_projector.petsc_options["snes_rtol"] = 1.0e-6
 297        self._v_projector.petsc_options.delValue("ksp_monitor")
 298        self._v_projector.solve(zero_init_guess)
 299
 300        return
 301

 303    # def _setup_terms(self):
 304    #     self._v_projector.uw_function = self.darcy_flux
 305    #     self._v_projector._setup_terms()  # _setup_pointwise_functions()  #
 306    #     super()._setup_terms()

 318class SNES_Stokes(SNES_Stokes_SaddlePt):
 319    r"""
 320    This class provides functionality for a discrete representation
 321    of the Stokes flow equations assuming an incompressibility
 322    (or near-incompressibility) constraint.
 323
 324    $$
 325    \nabla \cdot
 326            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[
 327                    \boldsymbol{\tau} -  p \mathbf{I} \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} =
 328            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \mathbf{f} \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}}
 329    $$
 330
 331    $$
 332    \underbrace{\Bigl[ \nabla \cdot \mathbf{u} \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{f}_p} = 0
 333    $$
 334
 335    The flux term is a deviatoric stress ( $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ ) related to velocity gradients
 336      ( $\nabla \mathbf{u}$ ) through a viscosity tensor, $\eta$, and a volumetric (pressure) part $p$
 337
 338    $$
 339        \mathbf{F}: \quad \boldsymbol{\tau} = \frac{\eta}{2}\left( \nabla \mathbf{u} + \nabla \mathbf{u}^T \right)
 340    $$
 341
 342    The constraint equation, $\mathbf{f}_p = 0$ is incompressible flow by default but can be set
 343    to any function of the unknown  $\mathbf{u}$ and  $\nabla\cdot\mathbf{u}$
 344
 345    ## Properties
 346
 347      - The unknowns are velocities $\mathbf{u}$ and a pressure-like constraint paramter $\mathbf{p}$
 348
 349      - The viscosity tensor, $\boldsymbol{\eta}$ is provided by setting the `constitutive_model` property to
 350    one of the scalar `uw.constitutive_models` classes and populating the parameters.
 351    It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear
 352    or anisotropic.
 353
 354      - $\mathbf f$ is a volumetric source term (i.e. body forces)
 355      and is set by providing the `bodyforce` property.
 356
 357      - An Augmented Lagrangian approach to application of the incompressibility
 358    constraint is to penalise incompressibility in the Stokes equation by adding
 359    $ \lambda \nabla \cdot \mathbf{u} $ when the weak form of the equations is constructed.
 360    (this is in addition to the constraint equation, unlike in the classical penalty method).
 361    This is activated by setting the `penalty` property to a non-zero floating point value which adds
 362    the term in the `sympy` expression.
 363
 364      - A preconditioner is usually required for the saddle point system and this is provided
 365    though the `saddle_preconditioner` property. The default choice is $1/\eta$ for a scalar viscosity function.
 366
 367    ## Notes
 368
 369      - For problems with viscoelastic behaviour, the flux term contains the stress history as well as the
 370        stress and this term is a Lagrangian quantity that has to be tracked on a particle swarm.
 371
 372      - The interpolation order of the `pressureField` variable is used to determine the integration order of
 373    the mixed finite element method and is usually lower than the order of the `velocityField` variable.
 374
 375      - It is possible to set discontinuous pressure variables by setting the `p_continous` option to `False`
 376
 377    """
 378
 379    instances = 0
 380
 381    def __init__(
 382        self,
 383        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
 384        velocityField: Optional[uw.discretisation.MeshVariable] = None,
 385        pressureField: Optional[uw.discretisation.MeshVariable] = None,
 386        degree: Optional[int] = 2,
 387        p_continuous: Optional[bool] = True,
 388        solver_name: Optional[str] = "",
 389        verbose: Optional[bool] = False,
 390    ):
 391        super().__init__(
 392            mesh,
 393            velocityField,
 394            pressureField,
 395            None,
 396            None,
 397            degree,
 398            p_continuous,
 399            solver_name,
 400            verbose,
 401        )
 402
 403        # change this to be less generic
 404        if solver_name == "":
 405            self.name = "Stokes_{}_".format(self.instance_number)
 406
 407        self._degree = degree
 408        # User-facing operations are matrices / vectors by preference
 409
 410        # self.Unknowns.E = self.mesh.vector.strain_tensor(self.Unknowns.u.sym)
 411        self._Estar = None
 412
 413        # scalar 2nd invariant (incompressible)
 414        self._penalty = 0.0
 415        self._constraints = sympy.Matrix(
 416            (self.div_u,)
 417        )  # by default, incompressibility constraint
 418
 419        self._bodyforce = sympy.Matrix([[0] * self.mesh.dim])
 420
 421        self._setup_problem_description = self.stokes_problem_description
 422
 423        # this attrib records if we need to re-setup
 424        self.is_setup = False
 425
 426        self._constitutive_model = None
 427
 428        return
 429
 430    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
 431    def stokes_problem_description(self):
 432        dim = self.mesh.dim
 433
 434        # residual terms can be redefined here. We leave the
 435        # F0, F1, PF0 terms in place to allow injection of
 436        # additional terms. These are pre-defined to be zero
 437
 438        # terms that become part of the weighted integral
 439        self._u_f0 = self.F0 - self.bodyforce
 440        # Integration by parts into the stiffness matrix (constitutive terms)
 441        self._u_f1 = sympy.simplify(
 442            self.F1 + self.stress + self.penalty * self.div_u * sympy.eye(dim)
 443        )
 444
 445        # forces in the constraint (pressure) equations
 446        self._p_f0 = sympy.simplify(self.PF0 + sympy.Matrix((self.constraints)))
 447
 448        return
 449

 451    def DFDt(self):
 452        return self._DFDt

 454    @DFDt.setter
 455    def DFDt(self, DFDt: Union[SemiLagrangian_DDt, Lagrangian_DDt]):
 456        self._DFDt = DFDt

 459    @property

 462
 463    @DuDt.setter
 464    def DuDt(self, DuDt: Union[SemiLagrangian_DDt, Lagrangian_DDt]):
 465        self._DuDt = DuDt

 500    @property
 501    def CM_is_setup(self):
 502        return self._constitutive_model._solver_is_setup

 504    @property
 505    def strainrate(self):
 506        return sympy.Matrix(self.mesh.vector.strain_tensor(self.Unknowns.u.sym))
 507
 508    @property
 509    def strainrate_1d(self):
 510        return uw.maths.tensor.rank2_to_voigt(self.strainrate, self.mesh.dim)
 511
 512    @property
 513    def strainrate_star_1d(self):
 514        return uw.maths.tensor.rank2_to_voigt(self.strainrate_star, self.mesh.dim)

 516    # This should return standard viscous behaviour if strainrate_star is None
 517    @property
 518    def stress_deviator(self):
 519        return self.constitutive_model.flux  # strainrate, strain-rate history
 520
 521    @property
 522    def stress_deviator_1d(self):
 523        return uw.maths.tensor.rank2_to_voigt(self.stress_deviator, self.mesh.dim)  ##
 524
 525    @property
 526    def stress(self):
 527        return self.stress_deviator - sympy.eye(self.mesh.dim) * (self.p.sym[0])
 528
 529    @property
 530    def stress_1d(self):
 531        return uw.maths.tensor.rank2_to_voigt(self.stress, self.mesh.dim)
 532
 533    @property
 534    def div_u(self):
 535        # E = self.strainrate
 536        # divergence = E.trace()
 537        # return divergence
 538
 539        return self.mesh.vector.divergence(self.Unknowns.u.sym)
 540

 543        return self._constraints

 557        self.is_setup = False
 558        self._bodyforce = self.mesh.vector.to_matrix(value)

 562        return self._saddle_preconditioner
 563

 566        self.is_setup = False

 581class SNES_VE_Stokes(SNES_Stokes):
 582    r"""
 583    This class provides functionality for a discrete representation
 584    of the Stokes flow equations assuming an incompressibility
 585    (or near-incompressibility) constraint and with a flux history
 586    term included to allow for viscoelastic modelling.
 587
 588    $$
 589    \nabla \cdot
 590            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[
 591                    \boldsymbol{\tau} -  p \mathbf{I} \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} =
 592            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \mathbf{f} \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}}
 593    $$
 594
 595    $$
 596    \underbrace{\Bigl[ \nabla \cdot \mathbf{u} \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{f}_p} = 0
 597    $$
 598
 599    The flux term is a deviatoric stress ( $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ ) related to velocity gradients
 600      ( $\nabla \mathbf{u}$ ) through a viscosity tensor, $\eta$, and a volumetric (pressure) part $p$
 601
 602    $$
 603        \mathbf{F}: \quad \boldsymbol{\tau} = \frac{\eta}{2}\left( \nabla \mathbf{u} + \nabla \mathbf{u}^T \right)
 604    $$
 605
 606    The constraint equation, $\mathbf{f}_p = 0$ is incompressible flow by default but can be set
 607    to any function of the unknown  $\mathbf{u}$ and  $\nabla\cdot\mathbf{u}$
 608
 609    ## Properties
 610
 611      - The unknowns are velocities $\mathbf{u}$ and a pressure-like constraint paramter $\mathbf{p}$
 612
 613      - The viscosity tensor, $\boldsymbol{\eta}$ is provided by setting the `constitutive_model` property to
 614    one of the scalar `uw.constitutive_models` classes and populating the parameters.
 615    It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear
 616    or anisotropic.
 617
 618      - $\mathbf f$ is a volumetric source term (i.e. body forces)
 619      and is set by providing the `bodyforce` property.
 620
 621      - An Augmented Lagrangian approach to application of the incompressibility
 622    constraint is to penalise incompressibility in the Stokes equation by adding
 623    $ \lambda \nabla \cdot \mathbf{u} $ when the weak form of the equations is constructed.
 624    (this is in addition to the constraint equation, unlike in the classical penalty method).
 625    This is activated by setting the `penalty` property to a non-zero floating point value which adds
 626    the term in the `sympy` expression.
 627
 628      - A preconditioner is usually required for the saddle point system and this is provided
 629    though the `saddle_preconditioner` property. The default choice is $1/\eta$ for a scalar viscosity function.
 630
 631    ## Notes
 632
 633      - For problems with viscoelastic behaviour, the flux term contains the stress history as well as the
 634        stress and this term is a Lagrangian quantity that has to be tracked on a particle swarm.
 635
 636      - The interpolation order of the `pressureField` variable is used to determine the integration order of
 637    the mixed finite element method and is usually lower than the order of the `velocityField` variable.
 638
 639      - It is possible to set discontinuous pressure variables by setting the `p_continous` option to `False`
 640
 641    """
 642
 643    instances = 0
 644
 645    def __init__(
 646        self,
 647        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
 648        velocityField: Optional[uw.discretisation.MeshVariable] = None,
 649        pressureField: Optional[uw.discretisation.MeshVariable] = None,
 650        DFDt: Union[SemiLagrangian_DDt, Lagrangian_DDt] = None,
 651        degree: Optional[int] = 2,
 652        order: Optional[int] = 2,
 653        p_continuous: Optional[bool] = True,
 654        solver_name: Optional[str] = "",
 655        verbose: Optional[bool] = False,
 656    ):
 657        super().__init__(
 658            mesh,
 659            velocityField,
 660            pressureField,
 661            None,
 662            DFDt,
 663            degree,
 664            p_continuous,
 665            solver_name,
 666            verbose,
 667        )
 668
 669        # change this to be less generic
 670        if solver_name == "":
 671            self.name = "VE_Stokes_{}_".format(self.instance_number)
 672
 673        self._order = order
 674        # User-facing operations are matrices / vectors by preference
 675
 676        self._Estar = None
 677
 678        # scalar 2nd invariant (incompressible)
 679        self._penalty = 0.0
 680        self._constraints = sympy.Matrix(
 681            (self.div_u,)
 682        )  # by default, incompressibility constraint
 683
 684        self._bodyforce = sympy.Matrix([[0] * self.mesh.dim])
 685
 686        self._setup_problem_description = self.stokes_problem_description
 687
 688        # this attrib records if we need to re-setup
 689        self.is_setup = False
 690        self._constitutive_model = None
 691
 692        if self.Unknowns.DFDt is None:
 693            self.Unknowns.DFDt = uw.systems.ddt.SemiLagrangian(
 694                self.mesh,
 695                sympy.Matrix.zeros(self.mesh.dim, self.mesh.dim),
 696                self.u.sym,
 697                vtype=uw.VarType.SYM_TENSOR,
 698                degree=self.u.degree - 1,
 699                continuous=True,
 700                varsymbol=rf"{{F[ {self.u.symbol} ] }}",
 701                verbose=self.verbose,
 702                bcs=None,
 703                order=self._order,
 704                smoothing=0.0,
 705            )
 706
 707        return
 708
 709
 710class SNES_Projection(SNES_Scalar):
 711    r"""
 712    Solves $u = \tilde{f}$ where $\tilde{f}$ is a function that can be evaluated within an element and
 713    $u$ is a `meshVariable` with associated shape functions. Typically, the projection is used to obtain a
 714    continuous representation of a function that is not well defined at the mesh nodes. For example, functions of
 715    the spatial derivatives of one or more `meshVariable` (e.g. components of fluxes) can be mapped to continuous
 716    variables with a projection. More broadly it is a projection from one basis to another and its limitations should be
 717    evaluated within that context.
 718
 719    The projection implemented by creating a solver for this problem
 720
 721    $$
 722    \nabla \cdot
 723            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\alpha \nabla u \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} -
 724            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ u - \tilde{f} \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}} = 0
 725    $$
 726
 727    Where the term $\mathbf{F}$ provides a smoothing regularization. $\alpha$ can be zero.
 728    """
 729
 730    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
 731    def __init__(
 732        self,
 733        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
 734        u_Field: uw.discretisation.MeshVariable = None,
 735        degree=2,
 736        solver_name: str = "",
 737        verbose=False,
 738    ):
 739        super().__init__(
 740            mesh,
 741            u_Field,
 742            None,  # DuDt
 743            None,  # DFDt
 744            degree,
 745            solver_name,
 746            verbose,
 747        )
 748
 749        if solver_name == "":
 750            self.name = "SProj_{}_".format(self.instance_number)
 751
 752        self._setup_problem_description = self.projection_problem_description
 753        self.is_setup = False
 754        self._smoothing = 0.0
 755        self._uw_weighting_function = 1.0
 756        self._constitutive_model = uw.constitutive_models.Constitutive_Model(
 757            self.Unknowns
 758        )
 759
 760        return
 761
 762    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
 763    def projection_problem_description(self):
 764        # residual terms - defines the problem:
 765        # solve for a best fit to the continuous mesh
 766        # variable given the values in self.function
 767        # F0 is left in place for the user to inject
 768        # non-linear constraints if required
 769
 770        self._f0 = (
 771            self.F0 + (self.u.sym - self.uw_function) * self.uw_weighting_function
 772        )
 773
 774        # F1 is left in the users control ... e.g to add other gradient constraints to the stiffness matrix
 775
 776        self._f1 = self.F1 + self.smoothing * self.mesh.vector.gradient(self.u.sym)
 777
 778        return
 779
 780    @property
 781    def uw_function(self):
 782        return self._uw_function
 783
 784    @uw_function.setter
 785    def uw_function(self, user_uw_function):
 786        self.is_setup = False
 787        self._uw_function = sympy.Matrix([user_uw_function])
 788
 789    @property
 790    def smoothing(self):
 791        return self._smoothing
 792
 793    @smoothing.setter
 794    def smoothing(self, smoothing_factor):
 795        self.is_setup = False
 796        self._smoothing = sympify(smoothing_factor)
 797
 798    @property
 799    def uw_weighting_function(self):
 800        return self._uw_weighting_function
 801
 802    @uw_weighting_function.setter
 803    def uw_weighting_function(self, user_uw_function):
 804        self.is_setup = False
 805        self._uw_weighting_function = user_uw_function
 806
 807
 808## --------------------------------
 809## Project from pointwise vector
 810## functions to nodal point unknowns
 811##
 812## We can add boundary constraints in the usual way (parent class handles this)
 813## We can add smoothing (which takes the form of a viscosity term)
 814## We could consider an incompressibility constraint ... or remove null spaces
 815## --------------------------------

 818class SNES_Vector_Projection(SNES_Vector):
 819    r"""
 820    Solves $\mathbf{u} = \tilde{\mathbf{f}}$ where $\tilde{\mathbf{f}}$ is a vector function that can be evaluated within an element and
 821    $\mathbf{u}$ is a vector `meshVariable` with associated shape functions. Typically, the projection is used to obtain a
 822    continuous representation of a function that is not well defined at the mesh nodes. For example, functions of
 823    the spatial derivatives of one or more `meshVariable` (e.g. components of fluxes) can be mapped to continuous
 824    variables with a projection. More broadly it is a projection from one basis to another and its limitations should be
 825    evaluated within that context.
 826
 827    The projection is implemented by creating a solver for this problem
 828
 829    $$
 830    \nabla \cdot
 831            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\alpha \nabla \mathbf{u} \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} -
 832            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \mathbf{u} - \tilde{\mathbf{f}} \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}} = 0
 833    $$
 834
 835    Where the term $\mathbf{F}$ provides a smoothing regularization. $\alpha$ can be zero.
 836    """
 837
 838    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
 839    def __init__(
 840        self,
 841        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
 842        u_Field: uw.discretisation.MeshVariable = None,
 843        degree=2,
 844        solver_name: str = "",
 845        verbose=False,
 846    ):
 847        super().__init__(
 848            mesh,
 849            u_Field,
 850            None,  # DuDt
 851            None,  # DFDt
 852            degree,
 853            solver_name,
 854            verbose,
 855        )
 856
 857        if solver_name == "":
 858            solver_name = "VProj{}_".format(self.instance_number)
 859
 860        self._setup_problem_description = self.projection_problem_description
 861        self.is_setup = False
 862        self._smoothing = 0.0
 863        self._penalty = 0.0
 864        self._uw_weighting_function = 1.0
 865        self._constitutive_model = uw.constitutive_models.Constitutive_Model(
 866            self.Unknowns
 867        )
 868
 869        return
 870
 871    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
 872    def projection_problem_description(self):
 873        # residual terms - defines the problem:
 874        # solve for a best fit to the continuous mesh
 875        # variable given the values in self.function
 876        # F0 is left in place for the user to inject
 877        # non-linear constraints if required
 878
 879        self._f0 = (
 880            self.F0 + (self.u.sym - self.uw_function) * self.uw_weighting_function
 881        )
 882
 883        # F1 is left in the users control ... e.g to add other gradient constraints to the stiffness matrix
 884
 885        self._f1 = (
 886            self.F1
 887            + self.smoothing * self.Unknowns.E
 888            + self.penalty
 889            * self.mesh.vector.divergence(self.u.sym)
 890            * sympy.eye(self.mesh.dim)
 891        )
 892
 893        return
 894
 895    @property
 896    def uw_function(self):
 897        return self._uw_function
 898
 899    @uw_function.setter
 900    def uw_function(self, user_uw_function):
 901        self.is_setup = False
 902        self._uw_function = sympy.Matrix(user_uw_function)
 903
 904    @property
 905    def smoothing(self):
 906        return self._smoothing
 907
 908    @smoothing.setter
 909    def smoothing(self, smoothing_factor):
 910        self.is_setup = False
 911        self._smoothing = sympify(smoothing_factor)
 912
 913    @property
 914    def penalty(self):
 915        return self._penalty
 916
 917    @penalty.setter
 918    def penalty(self, value):
 919        self.is_setup = False
 920        symval = sympify(value)
 921        self._penalty = symval
 922
 923    @property
 924    def uw_weighting_function(self):
 925        return self._uw_weighting_function
 926
 927    @uw_weighting_function.setter
 928    def uw_weighting_function(self, user_uw_function):
 929        self.is_setup = False
 930        self._uw_weighting_function = user_uw_function

 933class SNES_Tensor_Projection(SNES_Projection):
 934    r"""
 935    Solves $\mathbf{u} = \tilde{\mathbf{f}}$ where $\tilde{\mathbf{f}}$ is a tensor-valued function that can be evaluated within an element and
 936    $\mathbf{u}$ is a tensor `meshVariable` with associated shape functions. Typically, the projection is used to obtain a
 937    continuous representation of a function that is not well defined at the mesh nodes. For example, functions of
 938    the spatial derivatives of one or more `meshVariable` (e.g. components of fluxes) can be mapped to continuous
 939    variables with a projection. More broadly it is a projection from one basis to another and its limitations should be
 940    evaluated within that context.
 941
 942    The projection implemented by creating a solver for this problem
 943
 944    $$
 945    \nabla \cdot
 946            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\alpha \nabla \mathbf{u} \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} -
 947            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \mathbf{u} - \tilde{\mathbf{f}} \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}} = 0
 948    $$
 949
 950    Where the term $\mathbf{F}$ provides a smoothing regularization. $\alpha$ can be zero.
 951
 952    Note: this is currently implemented component-wise as we do not have a native solver for tensor unknowns.
 953
 954    """
 955
 956    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
 957    def __init__(
 958        self,
 959        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
 960        tensor_Field: uw.discretisation.MeshVariable = None,
 961        scalar_Field: uw.discretisation.MeshVariable = None,
 962        degree=2,
 963        solver_name: str = "",
 964        verbose=False,
 965    ):
 966        self.t_field = tensor_Field
 967
 968        super().__init__(
 969            mesh=mesh,
 970            u_Field=scalar_Field,
 971            # DuDt=None,  # DuDt #### Not in in SNES_projection class
 972            # DFDt=None,  # DFDt #### Not in in SNES_projection class
 973            degree=degree,
 974            solver_name=solver_name,
 975            verbose=verbose,
 976        )
 977
 978        if solver_name == "":
 979            solver_name = "TProj{}_".format(self.instance_number)
 980
 981        return
 982
 983    ## Need to over-ride solve method to run over all components
 984
 985    def solve(self):
 986        # Loop over the components of the tensor. If this is a symmetric
 987        # tensor, we'll usually be given the 1d form to prevent duplication
 988
 989        # if self.t_field.sym_1d.shape != self.uw_function.shape:
 990        #     raise ValueError(
 991        #         "Tensor shapes for uw_function and MeshVariable are not the same"
 992        #     )
 993
 994        symm = self.t_field.sym.is_symmetric
 995
 996        for i in range(self.uw_function.shape[0]):
 997            for j in range(self.uw_function.shape[1]):
 998                if symm and j > i:
 999                    continue
1000
1001                self.uw_scalar_function = sympy.Matrix([[self.uw_function[i, j]]])
1002
1003                with self.mesh.access(self.u):
1004                    self.u.data[:, 0] = self.t_field[i, j].data[:]
1005
1006                # solver for the scalar problem
1007
1008                super().solve()
1009
1010                with self.mesh.access(self.t_field):
1011                    self.t_field[i, j].data[:] = self.u.data[:, 0]
1012
1013        # That might be all ...
1014
1015    # This is re-defined so it uses uw_scalar_function
1016
1017    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
1018    def projection_problem_description(self):
1019        # residual terms - defines the problem:
1020        # solve for a best fit to the continuous mesh
1021        # variable given the values in self.function
1022        # F0 is left in place for the user to inject
1023        # non-linear constraints if required
1024
1025        self._f0 = (
1026            self.F0
1027            + (self.u.sym - self.uw_scalar_function) * self.uw_weighting_function
1028        )
1029
1030        # F1 is left in the users control ... e.g to add other gradient constraints to the stiffness matrix
1031
1032        self._f1 = self.F1 + self.smoothing * self.mesh.vector.gradient(self.u.sym)
1033
1034        return
1035
1036    @property
1037    def uw_scalar_function(self):
1038        return self._uw_scalar_function
1039
1040    @uw_scalar_function.setter
1041    def uw_scalar_function(self, user_uw_function):
1042        self.is_setup = False
1043        self._uw_scalar_function = user_uw_function
1044

1046## --------------------------------
1047## Project from pointwise vector
1048## functions to nodal point unknowns
1049##
1050## We can add boundary constraints in the usual way (parent class handles this)
1051## We can add smoothing (which takes the form of a viscosity term)
1052## Here we add an incompressibility constraint
1053## --------------------------------
1054
1055
1056#################################################
1057# Characteristics-based advection-diffusion
1058# solver based on SNES_Poisson and swarm-to-nodes
1059#
1060# Note that the solve() method has the swarm
1061# handler.
1062#################################################
1063
1064
1065class SNES_AdvectionDiffusion_SLCN(SNES_Scalar):
1066    r"""
1067    This class provides a solver for the scalar Advection-Diffusion equation using the characteristics based Semi-Lagrange Crank-Nicholson method
1068    which is described in Spiegelman & Katz, (2006).
1069
1070    $$
1071    \color{Green}{\underbrace{ \Bigl[ \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} - \left( \mathbf{v} \cdot \nabla \right) u \Bigr]}_{\dot{\mathbf{f}}}} -
1072    \nabla \cdot
1073            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla u \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} =
1074            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ f \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}}
1075    $$
1076
1077    The term $\mathbf{F}$ relates diffusive fluxes to gradients in the unknown $u$. The advective flux that results from having gradients along
1078    the direction of transport (given by the velocity vector field $\mathbf{v}$ ) are included in the $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ term.
1079
1080    The term $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ involves upstream sampling to find the value $u^*$ which represents the value of $u$ at
1081    the points which later arrive at the nodal points of the mesh. This is achieved using a "hidden"
1082    swarm variable which is advected backwards from the nodal points automatically during the `solve` phase.
1083
1084    ## Properties
1085
1086      - The unknown is $u$.
1087
1088      - The velocity field is $\mathbf{v}$ and is provided as a `sympy` function to allow operations such as time-averaging to be
1089        calculated in situ (e.g. `V_Field = v_solution.sym`) **NOTE: no it's not. Currently it is a MeshVariable** this is the desired behaviour though.
1090
1091      - The diffusivity tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the `constitutive_model` property to
1092        one of the scalar `uw.constitutive_models` classes and populating the parameters.
1093        It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear
1094        or anisotropic.
1095
1096      - Volumetric sources of $u$ are specified using the $f$ property and can be any valid combination of `sympy` functions of position and
1097        `meshVariable` or `swarmVariable` types.
1098
1099      - The `theta` property sets $\theta$, the parameter that tunes between backward Euler $\theta=1$, forward Euler $\theta=0$ and
1100        Crank-Nicholson $\theta=1/2$. The default is to use the Crank-Nicholson value.
1101
1102    ## Notes
1103
1104      - The solver requires relatively high order shape functions to accurately interpolate the history terms.
1105        Spiegelman & Katz recommend cubic or higher degree for $u$ but this is not checked.
1106
1107    ## Reference
1108
1109    Spiegelman, M., & Katz, R. F. (2006). A semi-Lagrangian Crank-Nicolson algorithm for the numerical solution
1110    of advection-diffusion problems. Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems, 7(4). https://doi.org/10.1029/2005GC001073
1111
1112    """
1113
1114    def _object_viewer(self):
1115        from IPython.display import Latex, Markdown, display
1116
1117        super()._object_viewer()
1118
1119        ## feedback on this instance
1120        display(Latex(r"$\quad\mathrm{u} = $ " + self.u.sym._repr_latex_()))
1121        display(Latex(r"$\quad\mathbf{v} = $ " + self._V_fn._repr_latex_()))
1122        display(Latex(r"$\quad\Delta t = $ " + self.delta_t._repr_latex_()))
1123        display(Latex(r"$\quad\theta = $ " + self.theta._repr_latex_()))
1124
1125    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
1126    def __init__(
1127        self,
1128        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
1129        u_Field: uw.discretisation.MeshVariable,
1130        V_fn: Union[
1131            uw.discretisation.MeshVariable, sympy.Basic
1132        ],  # Should be a sympy function
1133        order: int = 1,
1134        solver_name: str = "",
1135        restore_points_func: Callable = None,
1136        verbose=False,
1137    ):
1138        ## Parent class will set up default values etc
1139        super().__init__(
1140            mesh,
1141            u_Field,
1142            None,
1143            None,
1144            u_Field.degree,
1145            solver_name,
1146            verbose,
1147        )
1148
1149        if solver_name == "":
1150            solver_name = "AdvDiff_slcn_{}_".format(self.instance_number)
1151
1152        if isinstance(V_fn, uw.discretisation._MeshVariable):
1153            self._V_fn = V_fn.sym
1154        else:
1155            self._V_fn = V_fn
1156
1157        # default values for properties
1158        self.f = sympy.Matrix.zeros(1, 1)
1159
1160        self._constitutive_model = None
1161
1162        # These are unique to the advection solver
1163        self.delta_t = 0.0
1164        self.is_setup = False
1165
1166        self.restore_points_to_domain_func = restore_points_func
1167        self._setup_problem_description = self.adv_diff_slcn_problem_description
1168
1169        ### Setup the history terms
1170
1171        self.Unknowns.DuDt = SemiLagrangian_DDt(
1172            self.mesh,
1173            u_Field.sym,
1174            self._V_fn,
1175            vtype=uw.VarType.SCALAR,
1176            degree=u_Field.degree,
1177            continuous=u_Field.continuous,
1178            varsymbol=u_Field.symbol,
1179            verbose=verbose,
1180            bcs=self.essential_bcs,
1181            order=order,
1182            smoothing=0.0,
1183        )
1184
1185        self.Unknowns.DFDt = SemiLagrangian_DDt(
1186            self.mesh,
1187            sympy.Matrix(
1188                [[0] * self.mesh.dim]
1189            ),  # Actual function is not defined at this stage
1190            self._V_fn,
1191            vtype=uw.VarType.VECTOR,
1192            degree=u_Field.degree - 1,
1193            continuous=True,
1194            varsymbol=rf"{{F[ {self.u.symbol} ] }}",
1195            verbose=verbose,
1196            bcs=None,
1197            order=order,
1198            smoothing=0.0,
1199        )
1200
1201        return
1202
1203    def adv_diff_slcn_problem_description(self):
1204        # f0 residual term
1205        self._f0 = self.F0 - self.f + self.DuDt.bdf() / self.delta_t
1206
1207        # f1 residual term
1208        self._f1 = self.F1 + self.DFDt.adams_moulton_flux()
1209
1210        return
1211
1212    @property
1213    def f(self):
1214        return self._f
1215
1216    @f.setter
1217    def f(self, value):
1218        self.is_setup = False
1219        self._f = sympy.Matrix((value,))
1220
1221    @property
1222    def V_fn(self):
1223        return self._V_fn
1224
1225    @property
1226    def delta_t(self):
1227        return self._delta_t
1228
1229    @delta_t.setter
1230    def delta_t(self, value):
1231        self.is_setup = False
1232        self._delta_t = sympify(value)
1233
1234    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
1235    def estimate_dt(self, v_factor=1.0, diffusivity=None):
1236        """
1237        Calculates an appropriate advective timestep for the given
1238        mesh and diffusivity configuration.
1239        """
1240
1241        ## If k is non-linear and depends on gradients, then this evaluation
1242        ## does not work, we instead need a projection.
1243
1244        if diffusivity is None:
1245            diffusivity = self.constitutive_model.Parameters.diffusivity
1246
1247        if isinstance(diffusivity, uw.discretisation._MeshVariable):
1248            diffusivity = diffusivity.sym[0]
1249
1250        if isinstance(diffusivity, sympy.Expr):
1251            k = uw.function.evaluate(
1252                sympy.sympify(diffusivity),
1253                self.mesh._centroids,
1254                self.mesh.N,
1255            )
1256            max_diffusivity = k.max()
1257        else:
1258            k = self.constitutive_model.Parameters.diffusivity
1259            max_diffusivity = k
1260
1261        ### required modules
1262        from mpi4py import MPI
1263
1264        ## get global max dif value
1265        comm = MPI.COMM_WORLD
1266        diffusivity_glob = comm.allreduce(max_diffusivity, op=MPI.MAX)
1267
1268        ### get the velocity values
1269        vel = uw.function.evaluate(
1270            self.V_fn,
1271            self.mesh._centroids,
1272            self.mesh.N,
1273        )
1274
1275        ### get global velocity from velocity field
1276        max_magvel = np.linalg.norm(vel, axis=1).max()
1277        max_magvel_glob = comm.allreduce(max_magvel, op=MPI.MAX)
1278
1279        ## get radius
1280        min_dx = self.mesh.get_min_radius()
1281
1282        ## estimate dt of adv and diff components
1283
1284        if max_magvel_glob == 0.0:
1285            dt_diff = (min_dx**2) / diffusivity_glob
1286            dt_estimate = dt_diff
1287        elif diffusivity_glob == 0.0:
1288            dt_adv = min_dx / max_magvel_glob
1289            dt_estimate = dt_adv
1290        else:
1291            dt_diff = (min_dx**2) / diffusivity_glob
1292            dt_adv = min_dx / max_magvel_glob
1293            dt_estimate = min(dt_diff, v_factor * dt_adv)
1294
1295        return dt_estimate
1296
1297    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
1298    def solve(
1299        self,
1300        zero_init_guess: bool = True,
1301        timestep: float = None,
1302        _force_setup: bool = False,
1303        verbose=False,
1304    ):
1305        """
1306        Generates solution to constructed system.
1307
1308        Params
1309        ------
1310        zero_init_guess:
1311            If `True`, a zero initial guess will be used for the
1312            system solution. Otherwise, the current values of `self.u` will be used.
1313        """
1314
1315        if timestep is not None and timestep != self.delta_t:
1316            self.delta_t = timestep  # this will force an initialisation because the functions need to be updated
1317
1318        if _force_setup:
1319            self.is_setup = False
1320
1321        if not self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup:
1322            self.is_setup = False
1323            self.DFDt.psi_fn = self.constitutive_model.flux.T
1324
1325        if not self.is_setup:
1326            self._setup_pointwise_functions(verbose)
1327            self._setup_discretisation(verbose)
1328            self._setup_solver(verbose)
1329
1330        # Update SemiLagrange Unknown and Flux terms
1331        # self.DuDt.update(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=False)
1332        # self.DFDt.update(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=False)
1333
1334        # super().solve(zero_init_guess, _force_setup)
1335
1336        self.DuDt.update_pre_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1337        self.DFDt.update_pre_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1338
1339        super().solve(zero_init_guess, _force_setup)
1340
1341        self.DuDt.update_post_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1342        self.DFDt.update_post_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1343
1344        self.is_setup = True
1345        self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup = True
1346
1347        return
1348

1350#################################################
1351# Swarm-based advection-diffusion
1352# solver based on SNES_Poisson and swarm-variable
1353# projection
1354#
1355#################################################
1356
1357
1358class SNES_AdvectionDiffusion(SNES_Scalar):
1359    r"""
1360    This class provides a solver for the scalar Advection-Diffusion equation using the characteristics based Semi-Lagrange Crank-Nicholson method
1361    which is described in Spiegelman & Katz, (2006).
1362
1363    $$
1364    \color{Green}{\underbrace{ \Bigl[ \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} - \left( \mathbf{v} \cdot \nabla \right) u \Bigr]}_{\dot{\mathbf{f}}}} -
1365    \nabla \cdot
1366            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla u \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} =
1367            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ f \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}}
1368    $$
1369
1370    The term $\mathbf{F}$ relates diffusive fluxes to gradients in the unknown $u$. The advective flux that results from having gradients along
1371    the direction of transport (given by the velocity vector field $\mathbf{v}$ ) are included in the $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ term.
1372
1373    The term $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ involves upstream sampling to find the value $u^*$ which represents the value of $u$ at
1374    the points which later arrive at the nodal points of the mesh. This is achieved using a "hidden"
1375    swarm variable which is advected backwards from the nodal points automatically during the `solve` phase.
1376
1377    ## Properties
1378
1379      - The unknown is $u$.
1380
1381      - The velocity field is $\mathbf{v}$ and is provided as a `sympy` function to allow operations such as time-averaging to be
1382        calculated in situ (e.g. `V_Field = v_solution.sym`) **NOTE: no it's not. Currently it is a MeshVariable** this is the desired behaviour though.
1383
1384      - The diffusivity tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the `constitutive_model` property to
1385        one of the scalar `uw.constitutive_models` classes and populating the parameters.
1386        It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear
1387        or anisotropic.
1388
1389      - Volumetric sources of $u$ are specified using the $f$ property and can be any valid combination of `sympy` functions of position and
1390        `meshVariable` or `swarmVariable` types.
1391
1392
1393
1394    """
1395
1396    def _object_viewer(self):
1397        from IPython.display import Latex, Markdown, display
1398
1399        super()._object_viewer()
1400
1401        ## feedback on this instance
1402        display(Latex(r"$\quad\mathrm{u} = $ " + self.u.sym._repr_latex_()))
1403        display(Latex(r"$\quad\mathbf{v} = $ " + self._V_fn._repr_latex_()))
1404        display(Latex(r"$\quad\Delta t = $ " + self.delta_t._repr_latex_()))
1405        display(Latex(r"$\quad\theta = $ " + self.theta._repr_latex_()))
1406
1407    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
1408    def __init__(
1409        self,
1410        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
1411        u_Field: uw.discretisation.MeshVariable,
1412        V_fn: Union[
1413            uw.discretisation.MeshVariable, sympy.Basic
1414        ],  # Should be a sympy function
1415        DuDt: Lagrangian_DDt = None,
1416        order: int = 1,
1417        solver_name: str = "",
1418        restore_points_func: Callable = None,
1419        verbose=False,
1420    ):
1421        ## Parent class will set up default values etc
1422        super().__init__(
1423            mesh,
1424            u_Field,
1425            None,
1426            None,
1427            u_Field.degree,
1428            solver_name,
1429            verbose,
1430        )
1431
1432        if solver_name == "":
1433            solver_name = "AdvDiff_slcn_{}_".format(self.instance_number)
1434
1435        if isinstance(V_fn, uw.discretisation._MeshVariable):
1436            self._V_fn = V_fn.sym
1437        else:
1438            self._V_fn = V_fn
1439
1440        # default values for properties
1441        self.f = sympy.Matrix.zeros(1, 1)
1442
1443        self._constitutive_model = None
1444
1445        # These are unique to the advection solver
1446        self.delta_t = 0.0
1447        self.is_setup = False
1448
1449        self.restore_points_to_domain_func = restore_points_func
1450        self._setup_problem_description = self.adv_diff_slcn_problem_description
1451
1452        ### Setup the history terms ... This version should not build anything
1453        ### by default - it's the template / skeleton
1454
1455        if DuDt is None:
1456            self.Unknowns.DuDt = SemiLagrangian_DDt(
1457                self.mesh,
1458                u_Field.sym,
1459                self._V_fn,
1460                vtype=uw.VarType.SCALAR,
1461                degree=u_Field.degree,
1462                continuous=u_Field.continuous,
1463                varsymbol=u_Field.symbol,
1464                verbose=verbose,
1465                bcs=self.essential_bcs,
1466                order=order,
1467                smoothing=0.0,
1468            )
1469
1470        else:
1471            # validation
1472            if order is None:
1473                order = DuDt.order
1474
1475            else:
1476                if DuDt.order < order:
1477                    raise RuntimeError(
1478                        f"DuDt supplied is order {DuDt.order} but order requested is {order}"
1479                    )
1480
1481            self.Unknowns.DuDt = DuDt
1482
1483        self.Unknowns.DFDt = SemiLagrangian_DDt(
1484            self.mesh,
1485            sympy.Matrix(
1486                [[0] * self.mesh.dim]
1487            ),  # Actual function is not defined at this point
1488            self._V_fn,
1489            vtype=uw.VarType.VECTOR,
1490            degree=u_Field.degree - 1,
1491            continuous=False,
1492            varsymbol=rf"{{F[ {self.u.symbol} ] }}",
1493            verbose=verbose,
1494            bcs=None,
1495            order=order,
1496            smoothing=0.0,
1497        )
1498
1499        return
1500
1501    def adv_diff_slcn_problem_description(self):
1502        # f0 residual term
1503        self._f0 = self.F0 - self.f + self.DuDt.bdf() / self.delta_t
1504
1505        # f1 residual term
1506        self._f1 = self.F1 + self.DFDt.adams_moulton_flux()
1507
1508        return
1509

1529        self.is_setup = False
1530        self._delta_t = sympify(value)

1532    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
1533    def estimate_dt(self):
1534        """
1535        Calculates an appropriate advective timestep for the given
1536        mesh and diffusivity configuration.
1537        """
1538
1539        if isinstance(self.constitutive_model.Parameters.diffusivity, sympy.Expr):
1540            k = uw.function.evaluate(
1541                sympy.sympify(self.constitutive_model.Parameters.diffusivity),
1542                self.mesh._centroids,
1543                self.mesh.N,
1544            )
1545            max_diffusivity = k.max()
1546        else:
1547            k = self.constitutive_model.Parameters.diffusivity
1548            max_diffusivity = k
1549
1550        ### required modules
1551        from mpi4py import MPI
1552
1553        ## get global max dif value
1554        comm = MPI.COMM_WORLD
1555        diffusivity_glob = comm.allreduce(max_diffusivity, op=MPI.MAX)
1556
1557        ### get the velocity values
1558        vel = uw.function.evaluate(
1559            self.V_fn,
1560            self.mesh._centroids,
1561            self.mesh.N,
1562        )
1563
1564        ### get global velocity from velocity field
1565        max_magvel = np.linalg.norm(vel, axis=1).max()
1566        max_magvel_glob = comm.allreduce(max_magvel, op=MPI.MAX)
1567
1568        ## get radius
1569        min_dx = self.mesh.get_min_radius()
1570
1571        ## estimate dt of adv and diff components
1572
1573        if max_magvel_glob == 0.0:
1574            dt_diff = (min_dx**2) / diffusivity_glob
1575            dt_estimate = dt_diff
1576        elif diffusivity_glob == 0.0:
1577            dt_adv = min_dx / max_magvel_glob
1578            dt_estimate = dt_adv
1579        else:
1580            dt_diff = (min_dx**2) / diffusivity_glob
1581            dt_adv = min_dx / max_magvel_glob
1582            dt_estimate = min(dt_diff, dt_adv)
1583
1584        return dt_estimate
1585
1586    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
1587    def solve(
1588        self,
1589        zero_init_guess: bool = True,
1590        timestep: float = None,
1591        _force_setup: bool = False,
1592        verbose=False,
1593    ):
1594        """
1595        Generates solution to constructed system.
1596
1597        Params
1598        ------
1599        zero_init_guess:
1600            If `True`, a zero initial guess will be used for the
1601            system solution. Otherwise, the current values of `self.u` will be used.
1602        """
1603
1604        if timestep is not None and timestep != self.delta_t:
1605            self.delta_t = timestep  # this will force an initialisation because the functions need to be updated
1606
1607        if _force_setup:
1608            self.is_setup = False
1609
1610        if not self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup:
1611            self.is_setup = False
1612            self.DFDt.psi_fn = self.constitutive_model.flux.T
1613
1614        if not self.is_setup:
1615            self._setup_pointwise_functions(verbose)
1616            self._setup_discretisation(verbose)
1617            self._setup_solver(verbose)
1618
1619        # Update History / Flux History terms
1620        # SemiLagrange and Lagrange may have different sequencing.
1621        self.DuDt.update_pre_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1622        self.DFDt.update_pre_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1623
1624        super().solve(zero_init_guess, _force_setup)
1625
1626        self.DuDt.update_post_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1627        self.DFDt.update_post_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1628
1629        self.is_setup = True
1630        self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup = True
1631
1632        return
1633

1645
1646class SNES_AdvectionDiffusion_Swarm_old(SNES_Scalar):
1647    r"""
1648    This class provides a solver for the scalar Advection-Diffusion equation which is similar to that
1649    used in the Semi-Lagrange Crank-Nicholson method (Spiegelman & Katz, 2006) but using a
1650    distributed sampling of upstream values taken from an arbitrary swarm variable.
1651
1652    $$
1653    \color{Green}{\underbrace{ \Bigl[ \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} - \left( \mathbf{v} \cdot \nabla \right) u \Bigr]}_{\dot{\mathbf{f}}}} -
1654    \nabla \cdot
1655            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla u \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} =
1656            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ f \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}}
1657    $$
1658
1659    The term $\mathbf{F}$ relates diffusive fluxes to gradients in the unknown $u$. The advective flux that results from having gradients along
1660    the direction of transport (given by the velocity vector field $\mathbf{v}$ ) are included in the $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ term.
1661
1662    The term $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ involves upstream sampling to find the value $u^*$ which represents the value of $u$ at
1663    the beginning of the timestep. This is achieved using a `swarmVariable` that carries history information along the flow path.
1664    A dense sampling is required to achieve similar accuracy to the original SLCN approach but it allows the use of a single swarm
1665    for history tracking of variables with different interpolation order and for material tracking. The user is required to supply
1666    **and update** the swarmVariable representing $u^*$
1667
1668    ## Properties
1669
1670      - The unknown is $u$.
1671
1672      - The velocity field is $\mathbf{v}$ and is provided as a `sympy` function to allow operations such as time-averaging to be
1673        calculated in situ (e.g. `V_Field = v_solution.sym`)
1674
1675      - The history variable is $u^*$ and is provided in the form of a `sympy` function. It is the user's responsibility to keep this
1676        variable updated.
1677
1678      - The diffusivity tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the `constitutive_model` property to
1679        one of the scalar `uw.constitutive_models` classes and populating the parameters.
1680        It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear
1681        or anisotropic.
1682
1683      - Volumetric sources of $u$ are specified using the $f$ property and can be any valid combination of `sympy` functions of position and
1684        `meshVariable` or `swarmVariable` types.
1685
1686      - The `theta` property sets $\theta$, the parameter that tunes between backward Euler $\theta=1$, forward Euler $\theta=0$ and
1687        Crank-Nicholson $\theta=1/2$. The default is to use the Crank-Nicholson value.
1688
1689    ## Notes
1690
1691      - The solver requires relatively high order shape functions to accurately interpolate the history terms.
1692        Spiegelman & Katz recommend cubic or higher degree for $u$ but this is not checked.
1693
1694    ## Reference
1695
1696    Spiegelman, M., & Katz, R. F. (2006). A semi-Lagrangian Crank-Nicolson algorithm for the numerical solution
1697    of advection-diffusion problems. Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems, 7(4). https://doi.org/10.1029/2005GC001073
1698    """
1699
1700    instances = 0  # count how many of these there are in order to create unique private mesh variable ids
1701
1702    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
1703    def __init__(
1704        self,
1705        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
1706        u_Field: uw.discretisation.MeshVariable,
1707        V_fn: Union[
1708            uw.discretisation.MeshVariable, sympy.Basic
1709        ],  # Should be a sympy function
1710        DuDt: Lagrangian_DDt,
1711        solver_name: str = "",
1712        restore_points_func: Callable = None,
1713        verbose=False,
1714    ):
1715        if solver_name == "":
1716            solver_name = "AdvDiff_swarm_{}_".format(self.instance_number)
1717
1718        ## Parent class will set up default values etc
1719        super().__init__(
1720            mesh,
1721            u_Field,
1722            DuDt,
1723            DFDt,
1724            solver_name,
1725            verbose,
1726        )
1727
1728        self.delta_t = 1.0
1729        self.restore_points_to_domain_func = restore_points_func
1730        self._setup_problem_description = self.adv_diff_swarm_problem_description
1731
1732        self.is_setup = False
1733        self.u_star_is_valid = False
1734
1735        if isinstance(V_fn, uw.discretisation._MeshVariable):
1736            self._V_fn = V_fn.sym
1737        else:
1738            self._V_fn = V_fn
1739
1740        # default values for properties
1741        self.f = sympy.Matrix.zeros(1, 1)
1742        self._constitutive_model = None
1743
1744        return

1810    @constitutive_model.setter
1811    def constitutive_model(self, model):
1812        ### checking if it's an instance
1813        if isinstance(model, uw.constitutive_models.Constitutive_Model):
1814            self._constitutive_model = model
1815
1816            ### update history terms using setters
1817            self.DFDt.psi_fn = model._q(self.Unknowns.u)
1818
1819        ### checking if it's a class
1820        elif type(model) == type(uw.constitutive_models.Constitutive_Model):
1821            self._constitutive_model = model(self.Unknowns)
1822
1823            ### update history terms using setters
1824            self.DFDt.psi_fn = model._q(self.u)
1825
1826        ### Raise an error if it's neither
1827        else:
1828            raise RuntimeError(
1829                "constitutive_model must be a valid class or instance of a valid class"
1830            )

1889            dt_diff = (min_dx**2) / diffusivity_glob
1890            dt_adv = min_dx / max_magvel_glob
1891            dt_estimate = min(dt_diff, dt_adv)
1892
1893        return dt_estimate
1894
1895    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
1896    def solve(
1897        self,
1898        zero_init_guess: bool = True,
1899        timestep: float = None,
1900        _force_setup: bool = False,
1901        verbose=False,
1902    ):
1903        """
1904        Generates solution to constructed system.
1905
1906        Params
1907        ------
1908        zero_init_guess:
1909            If `True`, a zero initial guess will be used for the
1910            system solution. Otherwise, the current values of `self.u` will be used.
1911        """
1912
1913        if timestep is not None and timestep != self.delta_t:
1914            self.delta_t = timestep  # this will force an initialisation because the functions need to be updated
1915
1916        if _force_setup:
1917            self.is_setup = False
1918
1919        if not self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup:
1920            self.is_setup = False
1921            self.DFDt.psi_fn = self.constitutive_model.flux.T
1922
1923        if not self.is_setup:
1924            self._setup_pointwise_functions(verbose)
1925            self._setup_discretisation(verbose)
1926            self._setup_solver(verbose)
1927
1928        # Update SemiLagrange Flux terms
1929        self.DuDt.update(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1930        self.DFDt.update(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1931
1932        super().solve(zero_init_guess, _force_setup)
1933
1934        self.is_setup = True
1935        self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup = True
1936
1937        return
1938
1939    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
1940    def _setup_terms(self):
1941        if self.projection:
1942            self._u_star_projector.bcs = self.bcs
1943            self._u_star_projector._setup_pointwise_functions()  # _setup_terms()
1944
1945        super()._setup_pointwise_functions()  # ._setup_terms()
1946

1948## This one is already updated to work with the Semi-Lagrange D_Dt
1949class SNES_NavierStokes_SLCN(SNES_Stokes_SaddlePt):
1950    r"""
1951    This class provides a solver for the Navier-Stokes (vector Advection-Diffusion) equation which is similar to that
1952    used in the Semi-Lagrange Crank-Nicholson method (Spiegelman & Katz, 2006) but using a
1953    distributed sampling of upstream values taken from an arbitrary swarm variable.
1954
1955    $$
1956    \color{Green}{\underbrace{ \Bigl[ \frac{\partial \mathbf{u} }{\partial t} -
1957                                      \left( \mathbf{u} \cdot \nabla \right) \mathbf{u} \ \Bigr]}_{\dot{\mathbf{f}}}} -
1958        \nabla \cdot
1959            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \frac{\boldsymbol{\eta}}{2} \left(
1960                    \nabla \mathbf{u} + \nabla \mathbf{u}^T \right) - p \mathbf{I} \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} =
1961            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \mathbf{f} \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}}
1962    $$
1963
1964    The term $\mathbf{F}$ relates diffusive fluxes to gradients in the unknown $u$. The advective flux that results from having gradients along
1965    the direction of transport (given by the velocity vector field $\mathbf{v}$ ) are included in the $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ term.
1966
1967    The term $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ involves upstream sampling to find the value $u^{ * }$ which represents the value of $u$ at
1968    the beginning of the timestep. This is achieved using a `swarmVariable` that carries history information along the flow path.
1969    A dense sampling is required to achieve similar accuracy to the original SLCN approach but it allows the use of a single swarm
1970    for history tracking of variables with different interpolation order and for material tracking. The user is required to supply
1971    **and update** the swarmVariable representing $u^{ * }$
1972
1973    ## Properties
1974
1975      - The unknown is $u$.
1976
1977      - The velocity field is $\mathbf{v}$ and is provided as a `sympy` function to allow operations such as time-averaging to be
1978        calculated in situ (e.g. `V_Field = v_solution.sym`)
1979
1980      - The history variable is $u^*$ and is provided in the form of a `sympy` function. It is the user's responsibility to keep this
1981        variable updated.
1982
1983      - The diffusivity tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the `constitutive_model` property to
1984        one of the scalar `uw.constitutive_models` classes and populating the parameters.
1985        It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear
1986        or anisotropic.
1987
1988      - Volumetric sources of $u$ are specified using the $f$ property and can be any valid combination of `sympy` functions of position and
1989        `meshVariable` or `swarmVariable` types.
1990
1991    ## Notes
1992
1993      - The solver requires relatively high order shape functions to accurately interpolate the history terms.
1994        Spiegelman & Katz recommend cubic or higher degree for $u$ but this is not checked.
1995
1996    ## Reference
1997
1998    Spiegelman, M., & Katz, R. F. (2006). A semi-Lagrangian Crank-Nicolson algorithm for the numerical solution
1999    of advection-diffusion problems. Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems, 7(4). https://doi.org/10.1029/2005GC001073
2000    """
2001
2002    def _object_viewer(self):
2003        from IPython.display import Latex, Markdown, display
2004
2005        super()._object_viewer()
2006
2007        ## feedback on this instance
2008        display(Latex(r"$\quad\mathrm{u} = $ " + self.u.sym._repr_latex_()))
2009        display(Latex(r"$\quad\mathbf{p} = $ " + self.p.sym._repr_latex_()))
2010        display(Latex(r"$\quad\Delta t = $ " + self.delta_t._repr_latex_()))
2011        display(Latex(rf"$\quad\rho = $ {self.rho}"))
2012
2013    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
2014    def __init__(
2015        self,
2016        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
2017        velocityField: uw.discretisation.MeshVariable,
2018        pressureField: uw.discretisation.MeshVariable,
2019        rho: Optional[float] = 0.0,
2020        solver_name: Optional[str] = "",
2021        p_continuous: Optional[bool] = True,
2022        restore_points_func: Callable = None,
2023        verbose: Optional[bool] = False,
2024        order: Optional[int] = 1,
2025    ):
2026        ## Parent class will set up default values and load u_Field into the solver
2027
2028        super().__init__(
2029            mesh,
2030            velocityField,
2031            pressureField,
2032            None,
2033            None,
2034            order,
2035            p_continuous,
2036            solver_name,
2037            verbose,
2038        )
2039
2040        # These are unique to the advection solver
2041        self.delta_t = sympy.oo
2042        self.is_setup = False
2043        self.rho = rho
2044        self._first_solve = True
2045
2046        self._order = order
2047        self._constitutive_model = None
2048
2049        self._penalty = 0.0
2050        self._bodyforce = sympy.Matrix([[0] * self.mesh.dim])
2051
2052        # self._E = self.mesh.vector.strain_tensor(self.u.sym)
2053        self._Estar = None
2054
2055        self._constraints = sympy.Matrix((self.div_u,))
2056
2057        ### sets up DuDt and DFDt ...
2058
2059        self.Unknowns.DuDt = uw.systems.ddt.SemiLagrangian(
2060            self.mesh,
2061            self.u.sym,
2062            self.u.sym * bc_mask,
2063            vtype=uw.VarType.VECTOR,
2064            degree=self.u.degree,
2065            continuous=self.u.continuous,
2066            varsymbol=self.u.symbol,
2067            verbose=self.verbose,
2068            bcs=self.essential_bcs,
2069            order=self._order,
2070            smoothing=0.0,
2071        )
2072
2073        self.Unknowns.DFDt = uw.systems.ddt.SemiLagrangian(
2074            self.mesh,
2075            sympy.Matrix.zeros(self.mesh.dim, self.mesh.dim),
2076            self.u.sym,
2077            vtype=uw.VarType.SYM_TENSOR,
2078            degree=self.u.degree - 1,
2079            continuous=True,
2080            varsymbol=rf"{{F[ {self.u.symbol} ] }}",
2081            verbose=self.verbose,
2082            bcs=None,
2083            order=self._order,
2084            smoothing=0.0,
2085        )
2086
2087        self.restore_points_to_domain_func = restore_points_func
2088        self._setup_problem_description = self.navier_stokes_slcn_problem_description
2089
2090        return
2091
2092    def navier_stokes_slcn_problem_description(self):
2093        N = self.mesh.N
2094
2095        # f0 residual term
2096        self._u_f0 = (
2097            self.F0
2098            - self.bodyforce
2099            + self.rho * self.Unknowns.DuDt.bdf() / self.delta_t
2100        )
2101
2102        # f1 residual term
2103        self._u_f1 = (
2104            self.F1
2105            + self.Unknowns.DFDt.adams_moulton_flux()
2106            - sympy.eye(self.mesh.dim) * (self.p.sym[0])
2107        )
2108        self._p_f0 = sympy.simplify(self.PF0 + sympy.Matrix((self.constraints)))
2109
2110        return

2207        timestep: float = None,
2208        _force_setup: bool = False,
2209        verbose=False,
2210    ):
2211        """
2212        Generates solution to constructed system.
2213
2214        Params
2215        ------
2216        zero_init_guess:
2217            If `True`, a zero initial guess will be used for the
2218            system solution. Otherwise, the current values of `self.u` will be used.
2219        """
2220
2221        if timestep is not None and timestep != self.delta_t:
2222            self.delta_t = timestep  # this will force an initialisation because the functions need to be updated
2223
2224        if _force_setup:
2225            self.is_setup = False
2226
2227        if not self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup:
2228            self.is_setup = False
2229            self.Unknowns.DFDt.psi_fn = self.constitutive_model.flux.T
2230
2231        if not self.is_setup:
2232            self._setup_pointwise_functions(verbose)
2233            self._setup_discretisation(verbose)
2234            self._setup_solver(verbose)
2235
2236        # Update SemiLagrange Flux terms (May need to update to match pre-post solve pattern)
2237        self.Unknowns.DuDt.update(timestep, verbose=verbose)
2238        self.Unknowns.DFDt.update(timestep, verbose=verbose)
2239
2240        super().solve(
2241            zero_init_guess,
2242            _force_setup=_force_setup,
2243            verbose=verbose,
2244            picard=0,
2245        )
2246
2247        self.is_setup = True
2248        self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup = True
2249
2250        return

2523        symval = sympify(value)
2524        self._penalty = symval
2525
2526    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
2527    def solve(
2528        self,
2529        zero_init_guess: bool = True,
2530        timestep: float = None,
2531        _force_setup: bool = False,
2532        verbose=False,
2533        evalf=False,
2534        order=None,
2535    ):
2536        """
2537        Generates solution to constructed system.
2538
2539        Params
2540        ------
2541        zero_init_guess:
2542            If `True`, a zero initial guess will be used for the
2543            system solution. Otherwise, the current values of `self.u` will be used.
2544        """
2545
2546        if order is None or order > self._order:
2547            order = self._order
2548
2549        if timestep is not None and timestep != self.delta_t:
2550            self.delta_t = timestep  # this will force an initialisation because the functions need to be updated
2551
2552        if _force_setup:
2553            self.is_setup = False
2554
2555        if not self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup:
2556            self.is_setup = False
2557            self.DFDt.psi_fn = self.constitutive_model.flux.T
2558
2559        if not self.is_setup:
2560            self._setup_pointwise_functions(verbose)
2561            self._setup_discretisation(verbose)
2562            self._setup_solver(verbose)
2563
2564        if uw.mpi.rank == 0 and verbose:
2565            print(f"NS solver - pre-solve DuDt update", flush=True)
2566
2567        # Update SemiLagrange Flux terms
2568        self.DuDt.update_pre_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=evalf)
2569        self.DFDt.update_pre_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=evalf)
2570
2571        if uw.mpi.rank == 0 and verbose:
2572            print(f"NS solver - solve Stokes flow", flush=True)
2573
2574        super().solve(
2575            zero_init_guess,
2576            _force_setup=_force_setup,
2577            verbose=verbose,
2578            picard=0,
2579        )
2580
2581        if uw.mpi.rank == 0 and verbose:
2582            print(f"NS solver - post-solve DuDt update", flush=True)
2583
2584        self.DuDt.update_post_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=evalf)
2585        self.DFDt.update_post_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=evalf)
2586
2587        self.is_setup = True
2588        self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup = True
2589
2590        return

 33class SNES_Poisson(SNES_Scalar):
 34    r"""
 35    This class provides functionality for a discrete representation
 36    of the Poisson equation
 37
 38    $$
 39    \nabla \cdot
 40            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla u \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} =
 41            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ f \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}}
 42    $$
 43
 44    The term $\mathbf{F}$ relates the flux to gradients in the unknown $u$
 45
 46    ## Properties
 47
 48      - The unknown is $u$
 49
 50      - The diffusivity tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the `constitutive_model` property to
 51    one of the scalar `uw.constitutive_models` classes and populating the parameters.
 52    It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear
 53    or anisotropic.
 54
 55      - $f$ is a volumetric source term
 56    """

116class SNES_Darcy(SNES_Scalar):
117    r"""
118    This class provides functionality for a discrete representation
119    of the Groundwater flow equations
120
121    $$
122    \color{Green}{\underbrace{ \Bigl[  S_s \frac{\partial h}{\partial t} \Bigr]}_{\dot{\mathbf{f}}}} -
123    \nabla \cdot
124            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla h  - \boldsymbol{s}\Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} =
125            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ W \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}}
126    $$
127
128    The flux term, $\mathbf{F}$ relates the effective velocity to pressure gradients
129
130    $$
131    \boldsymbol{v} = \left( \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla h  - \boldsymbol{s} \right)
132    $$
133
134    The time-dependent term $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ is not implemented in this version.
135
136    ## Properties
137
138      - The unknown is $h$, the hydraulic head
139
140      - The permeability tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the `constitutive_model` property to
141    one of the scalar `uw.constitutive_models` classes and populating the parameters.
142    It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear
143    or anisotropic.
144
145      - Volumetric sources for the pressure gradient are supplied through
146        the $s$ property [e.g. $s = \rho g$ ]
147
148      - $W$ is a pressure source term
149
150      - $S_s$ is the specific storage coefficient
151
152    ## Notes
153
154      - The solver returns the primary field and also the Darcy flux term (the mean-flow velocity)
155
156    """
157

160        self,
161        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
162        h_Field: Optional[uw.discretisation.MeshVariable] = None,
163        v_Field: Optional[uw.discretisation.MeshVariable] = None,
164        degree: int = 2,

166        verbose=False,

184

186        self._f = sympy.Matrix([[0]])
187        self._k = 1
188

190        self._s[1] = -1
191

204

206        self._v_projector.smoothing = 0

212    def darcy_problem_description(self):
213        # f1 residual term (weighted integration)
214        self._f0 = self.F0 - self.f
215
216        # f1 residual term (integration by parts / gradients)
217        self._f1 = self.F1 + self.darcy_flux
218
219        # Flow calculation
220        self._v_projector.uw_function = -self.darcy_flux
221
222        return

This class provides functionality for a discrete representation of the Groundwater flow equations

$$ \color{Green}{\underbrace{ \Bigl[ S_s \frac{\partial h}{\partial t} \Bigr]}_{\dot{\mathbf{f}}}} - \nabla \cdot \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla h - \boldsymbol{s}\Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} = \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ W \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}} $$

The flux term, $\mathbf{F}$ relates the effective velocity to pressure gradients

$$ \boldsymbol{v} = \left( \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla h - \boldsymbol{s} \right) $$

The time-dependent term $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ is not implemented in this version.

Properties

  • The unknown is $h$, the hydraulic head

  • The permeability tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the constitutive_model property to one of the scalar uw.constitutive_models classes and populating the parameters. It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear or anisotropic.

  • Volumetric sources for the pressure gradient are supplied through the $s$ property [e.g. $s = \rho g$ ]

  • $W$ is a pressure source term

  • $S_s$ is the specific storage coefficient

Notes

  • The solver returns the primary field and also the Darcy flux term (the mean-flow velocity)
