class SNES_Stokes(underworld3.cython.generic_solvers.SNES_Stokes_SaddlePt): 
319class SNES_Stokes(SNES_Stokes_SaddlePt):
320    r"""
321    This class provides functionality for a discrete representation
322    of the Stokes flow equations assuming an incompressibility
323    (or near-incompressibility) constraint.
324
325    $$
326    \nabla \cdot
327            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[
328                    \boldsymbol{\tau} -  p \mathbf{I} \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} =
329            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \mathbf{f} \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}}
330    $$
331
332    $$
333    \underbrace{\Bigl[ \nabla \cdot \mathbf{u} \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{f}_p} = 0
334    $$
335
336    The flux term is a deviatoric stress ( $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ ) related to velocity gradients
337      ( $\nabla \mathbf{u}$ ) through a viscosity tensor, $\eta$, and a volumetric (pressure) part $p$
338
339    $$
340        \mathbf{F}: \quad \boldsymbol{\tau} = \frac{\eta}{2}\left( \nabla \mathbf{u} + \nabla \mathbf{u}^T \right)
341    $$
342
343    The constraint equation, $\mathbf{f}_p = 0$ is incompressible flow by default but can be set
344    to any function of the unknown  $\mathbf{u}$ and  $\nabla\cdot\mathbf{u}$
345
346    ## Properties
347
348      - The unknowns are velocities $\mathbf{u}$ and a pressure-like constraint paramter $\mathbf{p}$
349
350      - The viscosity tensor, $\boldsymbol{\eta}$ is provided by setting the `constitutive_model` property to
351    one of the scalar `uw.constitutive_models` classes and populating the parameters.
352    It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear
353    or anisotropic.
354
355      - $\mathbf f$ is a volumetric source term (i.e. body forces)
356      and is set by providing the `bodyforce` property.
357
358      - An Augmented Lagrangian approach to application of the incompressibility
359    constraint is to penalise incompressibility in the Stokes equation by adding
360    $ \lambda \nabla \cdot \mathbf{u} $ when the weak form of the equations is constructed.
361    (this is in addition to the constraint equation, unlike in the classical penalty method).
362    This is activated by setting the `penalty` property to a non-zero floating point value which adds
363    the term in the `sympy` expression.
364
365      - A preconditioner is usually required for the saddle point system and this is provided
366    though the `saddle_preconditioner` property. The default choice is $1/\eta$ for a scalar viscosity function.
367
368    ## Notes
369
370      - For problems with viscoelastic behaviour, the flux term contains the stress history as well as the
371        stress and this term is a Lagrangian quantity that has to be tracked on a particle swarm.
372
373      - The interpolation order of the `pressureField` variable is used to determine the integration order of
374    the mixed finite element method and is usually lower than the order of the `velocityField` variable.
375
376      - It is possible to set discontinuous pressure variables by setting the `p_continous` option to `False`
377
378    """
379
380    instances = 0
381
382    def __init__(
383        self,
384        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
385        velocityField: Optional[uw.discretisation.MeshVariable] = None,
386        pressureField: Optional[uw.discretisation.MeshVariable] = None,
387        degree: Optional[int] = 2,
388        p_continuous: Optional[bool] = True,
389        solver_name: Optional[str] = "",
390        verbose: Optional[bool] = False,
391    ):
392        super().__init__(
393            mesh,
394            velocityField,
395            pressureField,
396            None,
397            None,
398            degree,
399            p_continuous,
400            solver_name,
401            verbose,
402        )
403
404        # change this to be less generic
405        if solver_name == "":
406            self.name = "Stokes_{}_".format(self.instance_number)
407
408        self._degree = degree
409        # User-facing operations are matrices / vectors by preference
410
411        # self.Unknowns.E = self.mesh.vector.strain_tensor(self.Unknowns.u.sym)
412        self._Estar = None
413
414        # scalar 2nd invariant (incompressible)
415        self._penalty = 0.0
416        self._constraints = sympy.Matrix(
417            (self.div_u,)
418        )  # by default, incompressibility constraint
419
420        self._bodyforce = sympy.Matrix([[0] * self.mesh.dim])
421
422        self._setup_problem_description = self.stokes_problem_description
423
424        # this attrib records if we need to re-setup
425        self.is_setup = False
426
427        self._constitutive_model = None
428
429        return
430
431    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
432    def stokes_problem_description(self):
433        dim = self.mesh.dim
434
435        # residual terms can be redefined here. We leave the
436        # F0, F1, PF0 terms in place to allow injection of
437        # additional terms. These are pre-defined to be zero
438
439        # terms that become part of the weighted integral
440        self._u_f0 = self.F0 - self.bodyforce
441        # Integration by parts into the stiffness matrix (constitutive terms)
442        self._u_f1 = sympy.simplify(
443            self.F1 + self.stress + self.penalty * self.div_u * sympy.eye(dim)
444        )
445
446        # forces in the constraint (pressure) equations
447        self._p_f0 = sympy.simplify(self.PF0 + sympy.Matrix((self.constraints)))
448
449        return
450

453        return self._DFDt

This class provides functionality for a discrete representation of the Stokes flow equations assuming an incompressibility (or near-incompressibility) constraint.

$$ \nabla \cdot \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol{\tau} - p \mathbf{I} \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} = \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \mathbf{f} \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}} $$

$$ \underbrace{\Bigl[ \nabla \cdot \mathbf{u} \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{f}_p} = 0 $$

The flux term is a deviatoric stress ( $\boldsymbol{\tau}$ ) related to velocity gradients ( $\nabla \mathbf{u}$ ) through a viscosity tensor, $\eta$, and a volumetric (pressure) part $p$

$$ \mathbf{F}: \quad \boldsymbol{\tau} = \frac{\eta}{2}\left( \nabla \mathbf{u} + \nabla \mathbf{u}^T \right) $$

The constraint equation, $\mathbf{f}_p = 0$ is incompressible flow by default but can be set to any function of the unknown $\mathbf{u}$ and $\nabla\cdot\mathbf{u}$

Properties

  • The unknowns are velocities $\mathbf{u}$ and a pressure-like constraint paramter $\mathbf{p}$

  • The viscosity tensor, $\boldsymbol{\eta}$ is provided by setting the constitutive_model property to one of the scalar uw.constitutive_models classes and populating the parameters. It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear or anisotropic.

  • $\mathbf f$ is a volumetric source term (i.e. body forces) and is set by providing the bodyforce property.

  • An Augmented Lagrangian approach to application of the incompressibility constraint is to penalise incompressibility in the Stokes equation by adding $ \lambda \nabla \cdot \mathbf{u} $ when the weak form of the equations is constructed. (this is in addition to the constraint equation, unlike in the classical penalty method). This is activated by setting the penalty property to a non-zero floating point value which adds the term in the sympy expression.

  • A preconditioner is usually required for the saddle point system and this is provided though the saddle_preconditioner property. The default choice is $1/\eta$ for a scalar viscosity function.

Notes

  • For problems with viscoelastic behaviour, the flux term contains the stress history as well as the stress and this term is a Lagrangian quantity that has to be tracked on a particle swarm.

  • The interpolation order of the pressureField variable is used to determine the integration order of the mixed finite element method and is usually lower than the order of the velocityField variable.

  • It is possible to set discontinuous pressure variables by setting the p_continous option to False

@timing.routine_timer_decorator
def stokes_problem_description(self): 
431    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
432    def stokes_problem_description(self):
433        dim = self.mesh.dim
434
435        # residual terms can be redefined here. We leave the
436        # F0, F1, PF0 terms in place to allow injection of
437        # additional terms. These are pre-defined to be zero
438
439        # terms that become part of the weighted integral
440        self._u_f0 = self.F0 - self.bodyforce
441        # Integration by parts into the stiffness matrix (constitutive terms)
442        self._u_f1 = sympy.simplify(
443            self.F1 + self.stress + self.penalty * self.div_u * sympy.eye(dim)
444        )
445
446        # forces in the constraint (pressure) equations
447        self._p_f0 = sympy.simplify(self.PF0 + sympy.Matrix((self.constraints)))
448
449        return

class SNES_Projection(underworld3.cython.generic_solvers.SNES_Scalar): 
711class SNES_Projection(SNES_Scalar):
712    r"""
713    Solves $u = \tilde{f}$ where $\tilde{f}$ is a function that can be evaluated within an element and
714    $u$ is a `meshVariable` with associated shape functions. Typically, the projection is used to obtain a
715    continuous representation of a function that is not well defined at the mesh nodes. For example, functions of
716    the spatial derivatives of one or more `meshVariable` (e.g. components of fluxes) can be mapped to continuous
717    variables with a projection. More broadly it is a projection from one basis to another and its limitations should be
718    evaluated within that context.
719
720    The projection implemented by creating a solver for this problem
721
722    $$
723    \nabla \cdot
724            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\alpha \nabla u \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} -
725            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ u - \tilde{f} \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}} = 0
726    $$
727
728    Where the term $\mathbf{F}$ provides a smoothing regularization. $\alpha$ can be zero.
729    """
730
731    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
732    def __init__(
733        self,
734        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
735        u_Field: uw.discretisation.MeshVariable = None,
736        degree=2,
737        solver_name: str = "",
738        verbose=False,
739    ):
740        super().__init__(
741            mesh,
742            u_Field,
743            None,  # DuDt
744            None,  # DFDt
745            degree,
746            solver_name,
747            verbose,
748        )
749
750        if solver_name == "":
751            self.name = "SProj_{}_".format(self.instance_number)
752
753        self._setup_problem_description = self.projection_problem_description
754        self.is_setup = False
755        self._smoothing = 0.0
756        self._uw_weighting_function = 1.0
757        self._constitutive_model = uw.constitutive_models.Constitutive_Model(
758            self.Unknowns
759        )
760
761        return
762
763    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
764    def projection_problem_description(self):
765        # residual terms - defines the problem:
766        # solve for a best fit to the continuous mesh
767        # variable given the values in self.function
768        # F0 is left in place for the user to inject
769        # non-linear constraints if required
770
771        self._f0 = (
772            self.F0 + (self.u.sym - self.uw_function) * self.uw_weighting_function
773        )
774
775        # F1 is left in the users control ... e.g to add other gradient constraints to the stiffness matrix
776
777        self._f1 = self.F1 + self.smoothing * self.mesh.vector.gradient(self.u.sym)
778
779        return
780
781    @property
782    def uw_function(self):
783        return self._uw_function
784
785    @uw_function.setter
786    def uw_function(self, user_uw_function):
787        self.is_setup = False
788        self._uw_function = sympy.Matrix([user_uw_function])
789

791    def smoothing(self):
792        return self._smoothing

795    def smoothing(self, smoothing_factor):
796        self.is_setup = False
797        self._smoothing = sympify(smoothing_factor)

Solves $u = \tilde{f}$ where $\tilde{f}$ is a function that can be evaluated within an element and $u$ is a meshVariable with associated shape functions. Typically, the projection is used to obtain a continuous representation of a function that is not well defined at the mesh nodes. For example, functions of the spatial derivatives of one or more meshVariable (e.g. components of fluxes) can be mapped to continuous variables with a projection. More broadly it is a projection from one basis to another and its limitations should be evaluated within that context.

The projection implemented by creating a solver for this problem

$$ \nabla \cdot \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\alpha \nabla u \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} - \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ u - \tilde{f} \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}} = 0 $$

Where the term $\mathbf{F}$ provides a smoothing regularization. $\alpha$ can be zero.

@timing.routine_timer_decorator
SNES_Projection( mesh: underworld3.discretisation.Mesh, u_Field: <function MeshVariable> = None, degree=2, solver_name: str = '', verbose=False)

738        verbose=False,
739    ):

741            mesh,

743            None,  # DuDt

746            solver_name,
747            verbose,
748        )
749

751            self.name = "SProj_{}_".format(self.instance_number)
752
753        self._setup_problem_description = self.projection_problem_description
754        self.is_setup = False
755        self._smoothing = 0.0
756        self._uw_weighting_function = 1.0
757        self._constitutive_model = uw.constitutive_models.Constitutive_Model(
758            self.Unknowns
759        )

761        return

819class SNES_Vector_Projection(SNES_Vector):
820    r"""
821    Solves $\mathbf{u} = \tilde{\mathbf{f}}$ where $\tilde{\mathbf{f}}$ is a vector function that can be evaluated within an element and
822    $\mathbf{u}$ is a vector `meshVariable` with associated shape functions. Typically, the projection is used to obtain a
823    continuous representation of a function that is not well defined at the mesh nodes. For example, functions of
824    the spatial derivatives of one or more `meshVariable` (e.g. components of fluxes) can be mapped to continuous
825    variables with a projection. More broadly it is a projection from one basis to another and its limitations should be
826    evaluated within that context.
827
828    The projection is implemented by creating a solver for this problem
829
830    $$
831    \nabla \cdot
832            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\alpha \nabla \mathbf{u} \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} -
833            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \mathbf{u} - \tilde{\mathbf{f}} \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}} = 0
834    $$
835
836    Where the term $\mathbf{F}$ provides a smoothing regularization. $\alpha$ can be zero.
837    """
838
839    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
840    def __init__(
841        self,
842        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
843        u_Field: uw.discretisation.MeshVariable = None,
844        degree=2,
845        solver_name: str = "",
846        verbose=False,
847    ):
848        super().__init__(
849            mesh,
850            u_Field,
851            None,  # DuDt
852            None,  # DFDt
853            degree,
854            solver_name,
855            verbose,
856        )
857
858        if solver_name == "":
859            solver_name = "VProj{}_".format(self.instance_number)
860
861        self._setup_problem_description = self.projection_problem_description
862        self.is_setup = False
863        self._smoothing = 0.0
864        self._penalty = 0.0
865        self._uw_weighting_function = 1.0
866        self._constitutive_model = uw.constitutive_models.Constitutive_Model(
867            self.Unknowns
868        )

872    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
873    def projection_problem_description(self):
874        # residual terms - defines the problem:
875        # solve for a best fit to the continuous mesh
876        # variable given the values in self.function
877        # F0 is left in place for the user to inject
878        # non-linear constraints if required
879
880        self._f0 = (
881            self.F0 + (self.u.sym - self.uw_function) * self.uw_weighting_function
882        )
883
884        # F1 is left in the users control ... e.g to add other gradient constraints to the stiffness matrix
885
886        self._f1 = (
887            self.F1
888            + self.smoothing * self.Unknowns.E
889            + self.penalty
890            * self.mesh.vector.divergence(self.u.sym)
891            * sympy.eye(self.mesh.dim)
892        )
893
894        return

 934class SNES_Tensor_Projection(SNES_Projection):
 935    r"""
 936    Solves $\mathbf{u} = \tilde{\mathbf{f}}$ where $\tilde{\mathbf{f}}$ is a tensor-valued function that can be evaluated within an element and
 937    $\mathbf{u}$ is a tensor `meshVariable` with associated shape functions. Typically, the projection is used to obtain a
 938    continuous representation of a function that is not well defined at the mesh nodes. For example, functions of
 939    the spatial derivatives of one or more `meshVariable` (e.g. components of fluxes) can be mapped to continuous
 940    variables with a projection. More broadly it is a projection from one basis to another and its limitations should be
 941    evaluated within that context.
 942
 943    The projection implemented by creating a solver for this problem
 944
 945    $$
 946    \nabla \cdot
 947            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\alpha \nabla \mathbf{u} \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} -
 948            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \mathbf{u} - \tilde{\mathbf{f}} \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}} = 0
 949    $$
 950
 951    Where the term $\mathbf{F}$ provides a smoothing regularization. $\alpha$ can be zero.
 952
 953    Note: this is currently implemented component-wise as we do not have a native solver for tensor unknowns.
 954
 955    """
 956
 957    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
 958    def __init__(
 959        self,
 960        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
 961        tensor_Field: uw.discretisation.MeshVariable = None,
 962        scalar_Field: uw.discretisation.MeshVariable = None,
 963        degree=2,
 964        solver_name: str = "",
 965        verbose=False,
 966    ):
 967        self.t_field = tensor_Field
 968
 969        super().__init__(
 970            mesh=mesh,
 971            u_Field=scalar_Field,
 972            # DuDt=None,  # DuDt #### Not in in SNES_projection class
 973            # DFDt=None,  # DFDt #### Not in in SNES_projection class
 974            degree=degree,
 975            solver_name=solver_name,
 976            verbose=verbose,
 977        )
 978
 979        if solver_name == "":
 980            solver_name = "TProj{}_".format(self.instance_number)
 981
 982        return
 983
 984    ## Need to over-ride solve method to run over all components
 985
 986    def solve(self):
 987        # Loop over the components of the tensor. If this is a symmetric
 988        # tensor, we'll usually be given the 1d form to prevent duplication
 989
 990        # if self.t_field.sym_1d.shape != self.uw_function.shape:
 991        #     raise ValueError(
 992        #         "Tensor shapes for uw_function and MeshVariable are not the same"
 993        #     )
 994
 995        symm = self.t_field.sym.is_symmetric
 996
 997        for i in range(self.uw_function.shape[0]):
 998            for j in range(self.uw_function.shape[1]):
 999                if symm and j > i:
1000                    continue
1001
1002                self.uw_scalar_function = sympy.Matrix([[self.uw_function[i, j]]])
1003
1004                with self.mesh.access(self.u):
1005                    self.u.data[:, 0] = self.t_field[i, j].data[:]
1006
1007                # solver for the scalar problem
1008
1009                super().solve()
1010
1011                with self.mesh.access(self.t_field):
1012                    self.t_field[i, j].data[:] = self.u.data[:, 0]
1013
1014        # That might be all ...
1015
1016    # This is re-defined so it uses uw_scalar_function
1017

1019    def projection_problem_description(self):
1020        # residual terms - defines the problem:
1021        # solve for a best fit to the continuous mesh
1022        # variable given the values in self.function
1023        # F0 is left in place for the user to inject
1024        # non-linear constraints if required
1025
1026        self._f0 = (
1027            self.F0
1028            + (self.u.sym - self.uw_scalar_function) * self.uw_weighting_function
1029        )
1030
1031        # F1 is left in the users control ... e.g to add other gradient constraints to the stiffness matrix
1032
1033        self._f1 = self.F1 + self.smoothing * self.mesh.vector.gradient(self.u.sym)
1034
1035        return

class SNES_AdvectionDiffusion_SLCN(underworld3.cython.generic_solvers.SNES_Scalar): 
1066class SNES_AdvectionDiffusion_SLCN(SNES_Scalar):
1067    r"""
1068    This class provides a solver for the scalar Advection-Diffusion equation using the characteristics based Semi-Lagrange Crank-Nicholson method
1069    which is described in Spiegelman & Katz, (2006).
1070
1071    $$
1072    \color{Green}{\underbrace{ \Bigl[ \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} - \left( \mathbf{v} \cdot \nabla \right) u \Bigr]}_{\dot{\mathbf{f}}}} -
1073    \nabla \cdot
1074            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla u \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} =
1075            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ f \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}}
1076    $$
1077
1078    The term $\mathbf{F}$ relates diffusive fluxes to gradients in the unknown $u$. The advective flux that results from having gradients along
1079    the direction of transport (given by the velocity vector field $\mathbf{v}$ ) are included in the $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ term.
1080
1081    The term $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ involves upstream sampling to find the value $u^*$ which represents the value of $u$ at
1082    the points which later arrive at the nodal points of the mesh. This is achieved using a "hidden"
1083    swarm variable which is advected backwards from the nodal points automatically during the `solve` phase.
1084
1085    ## Properties
1086
1087      - The unknown is $u$.
1088
1089      - The velocity field is $\mathbf{v}$ and is provided as a `sympy` function to allow operations such as time-averaging to be
1090        calculated in situ (e.g. `V_Field = v_solution.sym`) **NOTE: no it's not. Currently it is a MeshVariable** this is the desired behaviour though.
1091
1092      - The diffusivity tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the `constitutive_model` property to
1093        one of the scalar `uw.constitutive_models` classes and populating the parameters.
1094        It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear
1095        or anisotropic.
1096
1097      - Volumetric sources of $u$ are specified using the $f$ property and can be any valid combination of `sympy` functions of position and
1098        `meshVariable` or `swarmVariable` types.
1099
1100      - The `theta` property sets $\theta$, the parameter that tunes between backward Euler $\theta=1$, forward Euler $\theta=0$ and
1101        Crank-Nicholson $\theta=1/2$. The default is to use the Crank-Nicholson value.
1102
1103    ## Notes
1104
1105      - The solver requires relatively high order shape functions to accurately interpolate the history terms.
1106        Spiegelman & Katz recommend cubic or higher degree for $u$ but this is not checked.
1107
1108    ## Reference
1109
1110    Spiegelman, M., & Katz, R. F. (2006). A semi-Lagrangian Crank-Nicolson algorithm for the numerical solution
1111    of advection-diffusion problems. Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems, 7(4). https://doi.org/10.1029/2005GC001073
1112
1113    """
1114
1115    def _object_viewer(self):
1116        from IPython.display import Latex, Markdown, display
1117
1118        super()._object_viewer()

1128        self,
1129        mesh: uw.discretisation.Mesh,
1130        u_Field: uw.discretisation.MeshVariable,
1131        V_fn: Union[
1132            uw.discretisation.MeshVariable, sympy.Basic
1133        ],  # Should be a sympy function
1134        order: int = 1,
1135        solver_name: str = "",
1136        restore_points_func: Callable = None,
1137        verbose=False,

1141            mesh,
1142            u_Field,
1143            None,
1144            None,
1145            u_Field.degree,
1146            solver_name,
1147            verbose,
1148        )
1149
1150        if solver_name == "":
1151            solver_name = "AdvDiff_slcn_{}_".format(self.instance_number)
1152
1153        if isinstance(V_fn, uw.discretisation._MeshVariable):
1154            self._V_fn = V_fn.sym
1155        else:
1156            self._V_fn = V_fn
1157
1158        # default values for properties
1159        self.f = sympy.Matrix.zeros(1, 1)
1160
1161        self._constitutive_model = None
1162

1164        self.delta_t = 0.0

1171

1173            self.mesh,
1174            u_Field.sym,
1175            self._V_fn,
1176            vtype=uw.VarType.SCALAR,
1177            degree=u_Field.degree,
1178            continuous=u_Field.continuous,
1179            varsymbol=u_Field.symbol,
1180            verbose=verbose,
1181            bcs=self.essential_bcs,
1182            order=order,
1183            smoothing=0.0,
1184        )
1185
1186        self.Unknowns.DFDt = SemiLagrangian_DDt(
1187            self.mesh,
1188            sympy.Matrix(
1189                [[0] * self.mesh.dim]
1190            ),  # Actual function is not defined at this stage
1191            self._V_fn,
1192            vtype=uw.VarType.VECTOR,
1193            degree=u_Field.degree - 1,
1194            continuous=True,
1195            varsymbol=rf"{{F[ {self.u.symbol} ] }}",
1196            verbose=verbose,
1197            bcs=None,
1198            order=order,
1199            smoothing=0.0,
1200        )
1201
1202        return

1204    def adv_diff_slcn_problem_description(self):
1205        # f0 residual term
1206        self._f0 = self.F0 - self.f + self.DuDt.bdf() / self.delta_t
1207
1208        # f1 residual term
1209        self._f1 = self.F1 + self.DFDt.adams_moulton_flux()
1210
1211        return

1235    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
1236    def estimate_dt(self, v_factor=1.0, diffusivity=None):
1237        """
1238        Calculates an appropriate advective timestep for the given
1239        mesh and diffusivity configuration.
1240        """
1241
1242        ## If k is non-linear and depends on gradients, then this evaluation
1243        ## does not work, we instead need a projection.
1244
1245        if diffusivity is None:
1246            diffusivity = self.constitutive_model.Parameters.diffusivity
1247
1248        if isinstance(diffusivity, uw.discretisation._MeshVariable):
1249            diffusivity = diffusivity.sym[0]
1250
1251        if isinstance(diffusivity, sympy.Expr):
1252            k = uw.function.evaluate(
1253                sympy.sympify(diffusivity),
1254                self.mesh._centroids,
1255                self.mesh.N,
1256            )
1257            max_diffusivity = k.max()
1258        else:
1259            k = self.constitutive_model.Parameters.diffusivity
1260            max_diffusivity = k
1261
1262        ### required modules
1263        from mpi4py import MPI
1264
1265        ## get global max dif value
1266        comm = MPI.COMM_WORLD
1267        diffusivity_glob = comm.allreduce(max_diffusivity, op=MPI.MAX)
1268
1269        ### get the velocity values
1270        vel = uw.function.evaluate(
1271            self.V_fn,
1272            self.mesh._centroids,
1273            self.mesh.N,
1274        )
1275
1276        ### get global velocity from velocity field
1277        max_magvel = np.linalg.norm(vel, axis=1).max()
1278        max_magvel_glob = comm.allreduce(max_magvel, op=MPI.MAX)
1279
1280        ## get radius
1281        min_dx = self.mesh.get_min_radius()
1282
1283        ## estimate dt of adv and diff components
1284
1285        if max_magvel_glob == 0.0:
1286            dt_diff = (min_dx**2) / diffusivity_glob
1287            dt_estimate = dt_diff
1288        elif diffusivity_glob == 0.0:
1289            dt_adv = min_dx / max_magvel_glob
1290            dt_estimate = dt_adv
1291        else:
1292            dt_diff = (min_dx**2) / diffusivity_glob
1293            dt_adv = min_dx / max_magvel_glob
1294            dt_estimate = min(dt_diff, v_factor * dt_adv)
1295
1296        return dt_estimate
1297
1298    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
1299    def solve(
1300        self,
1301        zero_init_guess: bool = True,
1302        timestep: float = None,
1303        _force_setup: bool = False,
1304        verbose=False,
1305    ):
1306        """
1307        Generates solution to constructed system.
1308
1309        Params
1310        ------
1311        zero_init_guess:
1312            If `True`, a zero initial guess will be used for the
1313            system solution. Otherwise, the current values of `self.u` will be used.
1314        """
1315
1316        if timestep is not None and timestep != self.delta_t:
1317            self.delta_t = timestep  # this will force an initialisation because the functions need to be updated
1318
1319        if _force_setup:
1320            self.is_setup = False
1321
1322        if not self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup:
1323            self.is_setup = False
1324            self.DFDt.psi_fn = self.constitutive_model.flux.T
1325
1326        if not self.is_setup:
1327            self._setup_pointwise_functions(verbose)
1328            self._setup_discretisation(verbose)
1329            self._setup_solver(verbose)
1330
1331        # Update SemiLagrange Unknown and Flux terms
1332        # self.DuDt.update(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=False)
1333        # self.DFDt.update(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=False)
1334
1335        # super().solve(zero_init_guess, _force_setup)
1336
1337        self.DuDt.update_pre_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1338        self.DFDt.update_pre_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1339
1340        super().solve(zero_init_guess, _force_setup)
1341
1342        self.DuDt.update_post_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1343        self.DFDt.update_post_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1344
1345        self.is_setup = True
1346        self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup = True
1347
1348        return

This class provides a solver for the scalar Advection-Diffusion equation using the characteristics based Semi-Lagrange Crank-Nicholson method which is described in Spiegelman & Katz, (2006).

$$ \color{Green}{\underbrace{ \Bigl[ \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} - \left( \mathbf{v} \cdot \nabla \right) u \Bigr]}_{\dot{\mathbf{f}}}} - \nabla \cdot \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla u \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} = \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ f \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}} $$

The term $\mathbf{F}$ relates diffusive fluxes to gradients in the unknown $u$. The advective flux that results from having gradients along the direction of transport (given by the velocity vector field $\mathbf{v}$ ) are included in the $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ term.

The term $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ involves upstream sampling to find the value $u^*$ which represents the value of $u$ at the points which later arrive at the nodal points of the mesh. This is achieved using a "hidden" swarm variable which is advected backwards from the nodal points automatically during the solve phase.

Properties

  • The unknown is $u$.

  • The velocity field is $\mathbf{v}$ and is provided as a sympy function to allow operations such as time-averaging to be calculated in situ (e.g. V_Field = v_solution.sym) NOTE: no it's not. Currently it is a MeshVariable this is the desired behaviour though.

  • The diffusivity tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the constitutive_model property to one of the scalar uw.constitutive_models classes and populating the parameters. It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear or anisotropic.

  • Volumetric sources of $u$ are specified using the $f$ property and can be any valid combination of sympy functions of position and meshVariable or swarmVariable types.

  • The theta property sets $\theta$, the parameter that tunes between backward Euler $\theta=1$, forward Euler $\theta=0$ and Crank-Nicholson $\theta=1/2$. The default is to use the Crank-Nicholson value.

Notes

  • The solver requires relatively high order shape functions to accurately interpolate the history terms. Spiegelman & Katz recommend cubic or higher degree for $u$ but this is not checked.

Reference

Spiegelman, M., & Katz, R. F. (2006). A semi-Lagrangian Crank-Nicolson algorithm for the numerical solution of advection-diffusion problems. Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems, 7(4). https://doi.org/10.1029/2005GC001073

1475
1476            else:
1477                if DuDt.order < order:
1478                    raise RuntimeError(
1479                        f"DuDt supplied is order {DuDt.order} but order requested is {order}"
1480                    )
1481
1482            self.Unknowns.DuDt = DuDt
1483
1484        self.Unknowns.DFDt = SemiLagrangian_DDt(
1485            self.mesh,
1486            sympy.Matrix(
1487                [[0] * self.mesh.dim]
1488            ),  # Actual function is not defined at this point
1489            self._V_fn,
1490            vtype=uw.VarType.VECTOR,
1491            degree=u_Field.degree - 1,
1492            continuous=False,
1493            varsymbol=rf"{{F[ {self.u.symbol} ] }}",
1494            verbose=verbose,
1495            bcs=None,
1496            order=order,
1497            smoothing=0.0,
1498        )
1499
1500        return
1501
1502    def adv_diff_slcn_problem_description(self):
1503        # f0 residual term
1504        self._f0 = self.F0 - self.f + self.DuDt.bdf() / self.delta_t
1505
1506        # f1 residual term
1507        self._f1 = self.F1 + self.DFDt.adams_moulton_flux()
1508
1509        return

1533    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
1534    def estimate_dt(self):
1535        """
1536        Calculates an appropriate advective timestep for the given
1537        mesh and diffusivity configuration.
1538        """
1539
1540        if isinstance(self.constitutive_model.Parameters.diffusivity, sympy.Expr):
1541            k = uw.function.evaluate(
1542                sympy.sympify(self.constitutive_model.Parameters.diffusivity),
1543                self.mesh._centroids,
1544                self.mesh.N,
1545            )
1546            max_diffusivity = k.max()
1547        else:
1548            k = self.constitutive_model.Parameters.diffusivity
1549            max_diffusivity = k
1550
1551        ### required modules
1552        from mpi4py import MPI
1553
1554        ## get global max dif value
1555        comm = MPI.COMM_WORLD
1556        diffusivity_glob = comm.allreduce(max_diffusivity, op=MPI.MAX)
1557
1558        ### get the velocity values
1559        vel = uw.function.evaluate(
1560            self.V_fn,
1561            self.mesh._centroids,
1562            self.mesh.N,
1563        )
1564
1565        ### get global velocity from velocity field
1566        max_magvel = np.linalg.norm(vel, axis=1).max()
1567        max_magvel_glob = comm.allreduce(max_magvel, op=MPI.MAX)
1568
1569        ## get radius
1570        min_dx = self.mesh.get_min_radius()
1571
1572        ## estimate dt of adv and diff components
1573
1574        if max_magvel_glob == 0.0:
1575            dt_diff = (min_dx**2) / diffusivity_glob
1576            dt_estimate = dt_diff
1577        elif diffusivity_glob == 0.0:
1578            dt_adv = min_dx / max_magvel_glob
1579            dt_estimate = dt_adv
1580        else:
1581            dt_diff = (min_dx**2) / diffusivity_glob
1582            dt_adv = min_dx / max_magvel_glob
1583            dt_estimate = min(dt_diff, dt_adv)
1584
1585        return dt_estimate
1586
1587    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
1588    def solve(
1589        self,
1590        zero_init_guess: bool = True,
1591        timestep: float = None,
1592        _force_setup: bool = False,
1593        verbose=False,
1594    ):
1595        """
1596        Generates solution to constructed system.
1597
1598        Params
1599        ------
1600        zero_init_guess:
1601            If `True`, a zero initial guess will be used for the
1602            system solution. Otherwise, the current values of `self.u` will be used.
1603        """
1604
1605        if timestep is not None and timestep != self.delta_t:
1606            self.delta_t = timestep  # this will force an initialisation because the functions need to be updated
1607
1608        if _force_setup:
1609            self.is_setup = False
1610
1611        if not self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup:
1612            self.is_setup = False
1613            self.DFDt.psi_fn = self.constitutive_model.flux.T
1614
1615        if not self.is_setup:
1616            self._setup_pointwise_functions(verbose)
1617            self._setup_discretisation(verbose)
1618            self._setup_solver(verbose)
1619
1620        # Update History / Flux History terms
1621        # SemiLagrange and Lagrange may have different sequencing.
1622        self.DuDt.update_pre_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1623        self.DFDt.update_pre_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1624
1625        super().solve(zero_init_guess, _force_setup)
1626
1627        self.DuDt.update_post_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1628        self.DFDt.update_post_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1629
1630        self.is_setup = True
1631        self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup = True
1632
1633        return

This class provides a solver for the scalar Advection-Diffusion equation using the characteristics based Semi-Lagrange Crank-Nicholson method which is described in Spiegelman & Katz, (2006).

$$ \color{Green}{\underbrace{ \Bigl[ \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} - \left( \mathbf{v} \cdot \nabla \right) u \Bigr]}_{\dot{\mathbf{f}}}} - \nabla \cdot \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla u \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} = \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ f \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}} $$

The term $\mathbf{F}$ relates diffusive fluxes to gradients in the unknown $u$. The advective flux that results from having gradients along the direction of transport (given by the velocity vector field $\mathbf{v}$ ) are included in the $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ term.

The term $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ involves upstream sampling to find the value $u^*$ which represents the value of $u$ at the points which later arrive at the nodal points of the mesh. This is achieved using a "hidden" swarm variable which is advected backwards from the nodal points automatically during the solve phase.

Properties

  • The unknown is $u$.

  • The velocity field is $\mathbf{v}$ and is provided as a sympy function to allow operations such as time-averaging to be calculated in situ (e.g. V_Field = v_solution.sym) NOTE: no it's not. Currently it is a MeshVariable this is the desired behaviour though.

  • The diffusivity tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the constitutive_model property to one of the scalar uw.constitutive_models classes and populating the parameters. It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear or anisotropic.

  • Volumetric sources of $u$ are specified using the $f$ property and can be any valid combination of sympy functions of position and meshVariable or swarmVariable types.

class SNES_AdvectionDiffusion_Swarm_old(underworld3.cython.generic_solvers.SNES_Scalar): 
1647class SNES_AdvectionDiffusion_Swarm_old(SNES_Scalar):
1648    r"""
1649    This class provides a solver for the scalar Advection-Diffusion equation which is similar to that
1650    used in the Semi-Lagrange Crank-Nicholson method (Spiegelman & Katz, 2006) but using a
1651    distributed sampling of upstream values taken from an arbitrary swarm variable.
1652
1653    $$
1654    \color{Green}{\underbrace{ \Bigl[ \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} - \left( \mathbf{v} \cdot \nabla \right) u \Bigr]}_{\dot{\mathbf{f}}}} -
1655    \nabla \cdot
1656            \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla u \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} =
1657            \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ f \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}}
1658    $$
1659
1660    The term $\mathbf{F}$ relates diffusive fluxes to gradients in the unknown $u$. The advective flux that results from having gradients along
1661    the direction of transport (given by the velocity vector field $\mathbf{v}$ ) are included in the $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ term.
1662
1663    The term $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ involves upstream sampling to find the value $u^*$ which represents the value of $u$ at
1664    the beginning of the timestep. This is achieved using a `swarmVariable` that carries history information along the flow path.
1665    A dense sampling is required to achieve similar accuracy to the original SLCN approach but it allows the use of a single swarm
1666    for history tracking of variables with different interpolation order and for material tracking. The user is required to supply
1667    **and update** the swarmVariable representing $u^*$
1668
1669    ## Properties
1670
1671      - The unknown is $u$.
1672
1673      - The velocity field is $\mathbf{v}$ and is provided as a `sympy` function to allow operations such as time-averaging to be
1674        calculated in situ (e.g. `V_Field = v_solution.sym`)
1675
1676      - The history variable is $u^*$ and is provided in the form of a `sympy` function. It is the user's responsibility to keep this
1677        variable updated.
1678
1679      - The diffusivity tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the `constitutive_model` property to
1680        one of the scalar `uw.constitutive_models` classes and populating the parameters.
1681        It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear
1682        or anisotropic.
1683
1684      - Volumetric sources of $u$ are specified using the $f$ property and can be any valid combination of `sympy` functions of position and
1685        `meshVariable` or `swarmVariable` types.
1686
1687      - The `theta` property sets $\theta$, the parameter that tunes between backward Euler $\theta=1$, forward Euler $\theta=0$ and
1688        Crank-Nicholson $\theta=1/2$. The default is to use the Crank-Nicholson value.
1689
1690    ## Notes
1691
1692      - The solver requires relatively high order shape functions to accurately interpolate the history terms.
1693        Spiegelman & Katz recommend cubic or higher degree for $u$ but this is not checked.
1694
1695    ## Reference
1696
1697    Spiegelman, M., & Katz, R. F. (2006). A semi-Lagrangian Crank-Nicolson algorithm for the numerical solution
1698    of advection-diffusion problems. Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems, 7(4). https://doi.org/10.1029/2005GC001073
1699    """

1813        ### checking if it's an instance
1814        if isinstance(model, uw.constitutive_models.Constitutive_Model):
1815            self._constitutive_model = model
1816
1817            ### update history terms using setters
1818            self.DFDt.psi_fn = model._q(self.Unknowns.u)
1819
1820        ### checking if it's a class
1821        elif type(model) == type(uw.constitutive_models.Constitutive_Model):
1822            self._constitutive_model = model(self.Unknowns)
1823
1824            ### update history terms using setters
1825            self.DFDt.psi_fn = model._q(self.u)
1826
1827        ### Raise an error if it's neither
1828        else:
1829            raise RuntimeError(
1830                "constitutive_model must be a valid class or instance of a valid class"

1846            k = uw.function.evaluate(
1847                sympy.sympify(self.constitutive_model.Parameters.diffusivity),
1848                self.mesh._centroids,
1849                self.mesh.N,
1850            )
1851            max_diffusivity = k.max()
1852        else:
1853            k = self.constitutive_model.Parameters.diffusivity
1854            max_diffusivity = k
1855
1856        ### required modules
1857        from mpi4py import MPI
1858
1859        # with self.mesh.access(self.k):
1860        #     ## get local max diff value
1861        #     max_diffusivity = self.k.data[:, 0].max()
1862
1863        ## get global max dif value
1864        comm = MPI.COMM_WORLD
1865        diffusivity_glob = comm.allreduce(max_diffusivity, op=MPI.MAX)
1866
1867        ### get the velocity values
1868        vel = uw.function.evaluate(
1869            self.V_fn,
1870            self.mesh._centroids,
1871            self.mesh.N,
1872        )
1873
1874        ### get global velocity from velocity field
1875        max_magvel = np.linalg.norm(vel, axis=1).max()
1876        max_magvel_glob = comm.allreduce(max_magvel, op=MPI.MAX)
1877
1878        ## get radius
1879        min_dx = self.mesh.get_min_radius()
1880
1881        ## estimate dt of adv and diff components
1882
1883        if max_magvel_glob == 0.0:
1884            dt_diff = (min_dx**2) / diffusivity_glob
1885            dt_estimate = dt_diff
1886        elif diffusivity_glob == 0.0:
1887            dt_adv = min_dx / max_magvel_glob
1888            dt_estimate = dt_adv
1889        else:
1890            dt_diff = (min_dx**2) / diffusivity_glob
1891            dt_adv = min_dx / max_magvel_glob
1892            dt_estimate = min(dt_diff, dt_adv)
1893
1894        return dt_estimate
1895
1896    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
1897    def solve(
1898        self,
1899        zero_init_guess: bool = True,
1900        timestep: float = None,
1901        _force_setup: bool = False,
1902        verbose=False,
1903    ):
1904        """
1905        Generates solution to constructed system.
1906
1907        Params
1908        ------
1909        zero_init_guess:
1910            If `True`, a zero initial guess will be used for the
1911            system solution. Otherwise, the current values of `self.u` will be used.
1912        """
1913
1914        if timestep is not None and timestep != self.delta_t:
1915            self.delta_t = timestep  # this will force an initialisation because the functions need to be updated
1916
1917        if _force_setup:
1918            self.is_setup = False
1919
1920        if not self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup:
1921            self.is_setup = False
1922            self.DFDt.psi_fn = self.constitutive_model.flux.T
1923
1924        if not self.is_setup:
1925            self._setup_pointwise_functions(verbose)
1926            self._setup_discretisation(verbose)
1927            self._setup_solver(verbose)
1928
1929        # Update SemiLagrange Flux terms
1930        self.DuDt.update(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1931        self.DFDt.update(timestep, verbose=verbose)
1932
1933        super().solve(zero_init_guess, _force_setup)
1934
1935        self.is_setup = True
1936        self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup = True
1937
1938        return

1942        if self.projection:

This class provides a solver for the scalar Advection-Diffusion equation which is similar to that used in the Semi-Lagrange Crank-Nicholson method (Spiegelman & Katz, 2006) but using a distributed sampling of upstream values taken from an arbitrary swarm variable.

$$ \color{Green}{\underbrace{ \Bigl[ \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} - \left( \mathbf{v} \cdot \nabla \right) u \Bigr]}_{\dot{\mathbf{f}}}} - \nabla \cdot \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \boldsymbol\kappa \nabla u \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} = \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ f \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}} $$

The term $\mathbf{F}$ relates diffusive fluxes to gradients in the unknown $u$. The advective flux that results from having gradients along the direction of transport (given by the velocity vector field $\mathbf{v}$ ) are included in the $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ term.

The term $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ involves upstream sampling to find the value $u^$ which represents the value of $u$ at the beginning of the timestep. This is achieved using a swarmVariable that carries history information along the flow path. A dense sampling is required to achieve similar accuracy to the original SLCN approach but it allows the use of a single swarm for history tracking of variables with different interpolation order and for material tracking. The user is required to supply and update the swarmVariable representing $u^$

Properties

  • The unknown is $u$.

  • The velocity field is $\mathbf{v}$ and is provided as a sympy function to allow operations such as time-averaging to be calculated in situ (e.g. V_Field = v_solution.sym)

  • The history variable is $u^*$ and is provided in the form of a sympy function. It is the user's responsibility to keep this variable updated.

  • The diffusivity tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the constitutive_model property to one of the scalar uw.constitutive_models classes and populating the parameters. It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear or anisotropic.

  • Volumetric sources of $u$ are specified using the $f$ property and can be any valid combination of sympy functions of position and meshVariable or swarmVariable types.

  • The theta property sets $\theta$, the parameter that tunes between backward Euler $\theta=1$, forward Euler $\theta=0$ and Crank-Nicholson $\theta=1/2$. The default is to use the Crank-Nicholson value.

Notes

  • The solver requires relatively high order shape functions to accurately interpolate the history terms. Spiegelman & Katz recommend cubic or higher degree for $u$ but this is not checked.

Reference

Spiegelman, M., & Katz, R. F. (2006). A semi-Lagrangian Crank-Nicolson algorithm for the numerical solution of advection-diffusion problems. Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems, 7(4). https://doi.org/10.1029/2005GC001073

2093    def navier_stokes_slcn_problem_description(self):
2094        N = self.mesh.N
2095
2096        # f0 residual term
2097        self._u_f0 = (
2098            self.F0
2099            - self.bodyforce
2100            + self.rho * self.Unknowns.DuDt.bdf() / self.delta_t
2101        )
2102
2103        # f1 residual term
2104        self._u_f1 = (
2105            self.F1
2106            + self.Unknowns.DFDt.adams_moulton_flux()
2107            - sympy.eye(self.mesh.dim) * (self.p.sym[0])
2108        )
2109        self._p_f0 = sympy.simplify(self.PF0 + sympy.Matrix((self.constraints)))
2110
2111        return

2225        if _force_setup:
2226            self.is_setup = False
2227
2228        if not self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup:
2229            self.is_setup = False
2230            self.Unknowns.DFDt.psi_fn = self.constitutive_model.flux.T
2231
2232        if not self.is_setup:
2233            self._setup_pointwise_functions(verbose)
2234            self._setup_discretisation(verbose)
2235            self._setup_solver(verbose)
2236
2237        # Update SemiLagrange Flux terms (May need to update to match pre-post solve pattern)
2238        self.Unknowns.DuDt.update(timestep, verbose=verbose)
2239        self.Unknowns.DFDt.update(timestep, verbose=verbose)

2242            zero_init_guess,
2243            _force_setup=_force_setup,

This class provides a solver for the Navier-Stokes (vector Advection-Diffusion) equation which is similar to that used in the Semi-Lagrange Crank-Nicholson method (Spiegelman & Katz, 2006) but using a distributed sampling of upstream values taken from an arbitrary swarm variable.

$$ \color{Green}{\underbrace{ \Bigl[ \frac{\partial \mathbf{u} }{\partial t} - \left( \mathbf{u} \cdot \nabla \right) \mathbf{u} \ \Bigr]}_{\dot{\mathbf{f}}}} - \nabla \cdot \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \frac{\boldsymbol{\eta}}{2} \left( \nabla \mathbf{u} + \nabla \mathbf{u}^T \right) - p \mathbf{I} \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} = \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \mathbf{f} \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}} $$

The term $\mathbf{F}$ relates diffusive fluxes to gradients in the unknown $u$. The advective flux that results from having gradients along the direction of transport (given by the velocity vector field $\mathbf{v}$ ) are included in the $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ term.

The term $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ involves upstream sampling to find the value $u^{ * }$ which represents the value of $u$ at the beginning of the timestep. This is achieved using a swarmVariable that carries history information along the flow path. A dense sampling is required to achieve similar accuracy to the original SLCN approach but it allows the use of a single swarm for history tracking of variables with different interpolation order and for material tracking. The user is required to supply and update the swarmVariable representing $u^{ * }$

Properties

  • The unknown is $u$.

  • The velocity field is $\mathbf{v}$ and is provided as a sympy function to allow operations such as time-averaging to be calculated in situ (e.g. V_Field = v_solution.sym)

  • The history variable is $u^*$ and is provided in the form of a sympy function. It is the user's responsibility to keep this variable updated.

  • The diffusivity tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the constitutive_model property to one of the scalar uw.constitutive_models classes and populating the parameters. It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear or anisotropic.

  • Volumetric sources of $u$ are specified using the $f$ property and can be any valid combination of sympy functions of position and meshVariable or swarmVariable types.

Notes

  • The solver requires relatively high order shape functions to accurately interpolate the history terms. Spiegelman & Katz recommend cubic or higher degree for $u$ but this is not checked.

Reference

Spiegelman, M., & Katz, R. F. (2006). A semi-Lagrangian Crank-Nicolson algorithm for the numerical solution of advection-diffusion problems. Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems, 7(4). https://doi.org/10.1029/2005GC001073

2419    def navier_stokes_problem_description(self):
2420        # f0 residual term
2421
2422        self._u_f0 = (
2423            self.F0 - self.bodyforce + self.rho * self.DuDt.bdf() / self.delta_t
2424        )

2430            - sympy.eye(self.mesh.dim) * (self.p.sym[0])
2431        )
2432        self._p_f0 = sympy.simplify(self.PF0 + sympy.Matrix((self.constraints)))

2527    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
2528    def solve(
2529        self,
2530        zero_init_guess: bool = True,
2531        timestep: float = None,
2532        _force_setup: bool = False,
2533        verbose=False,
2534        evalf=False,
2535        order=None,
2536    ):
2537        """
2538        Generates solution to constructed system.
2539
2540        Params
2541        ------
2542        zero_init_guess:
2543            If `True`, a zero initial guess will be used for the
2544            system solution. Otherwise, the current values of `self.u` will be used.
2545        """
2546
2547        if order is None or order > self._order:
2548            order = self._order
2549
2550        if timestep is not None and timestep != self.delta_t:
2551            self.delta_t = timestep  # this will force an initialisation because the functions need to be updated
2552
2553        if _force_setup:
2554            self.is_setup = False
2555
2556        if not self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup:
2557            self.is_setup = False
2558            self.DFDt.psi_fn = self.constitutive_model.flux.T
2559
2560        if not self.is_setup:
2561            self._setup_pointwise_functions(verbose)
2562            self._setup_discretisation(verbose)
2563            self._setup_solver(verbose)
2564
2565        if uw.mpi.rank == 0 and verbose:
2566            print(f"NS solver - pre-solve DuDt update", flush=True)
2567
2568        # Update SemiLagrange Flux terms
2569        self.DuDt.update_pre_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=evalf)
2570        self.DFDt.update_pre_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=evalf)
2571
2572        if uw.mpi.rank == 0 and verbose:
2573            print(f"NS solver - solve Stokes flow", flush=True)
2574
2575        super().solve(
2576            zero_init_guess,
2577            _force_setup=_force_setup,
2578            verbose=verbose,
2579            picard=0,
2580        )
2581
2582        if uw.mpi.rank == 0 and verbose:
2583            print(f"NS solver - post-solve DuDt update", flush=True)
2584
2585        self.DuDt.update_post_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=evalf)
2586        self.DFDt.update_post_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=evalf)
2587
2588        self.is_setup = True
2589        self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup = True
2590
2591        return

This class provides a solver for the Navier-Stokes (vector Advection-Diffusion) equation which is similar to that used in the Semi-Lagrange Crank-Nicholson method (Spiegelman & Katz, 2006) but using a distributed sampling of upstream values taken from an arbitrary swarm variable.

$$ \color{Green}{\underbrace{ \Bigl[ \frac{\partial \mathbf{u} }{\partial t} - \left( \mathbf{u} \cdot \nabla \right) \mathbf{u} \ \Bigr]}_{\dot{\mathbf{f}}}} - \nabla \cdot \color{Blue}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \frac{\boldsymbol{\eta}}{2} \left( \nabla \mathbf{u} + \nabla \mathbf{u}^T \right) - p \mathbf{I} \Bigr]}_{\mathbf{F}}} = \color{Maroon}{\underbrace{\Bigl[ \mathbf{f} \Bigl] }_{\mathbf{f}}} $$

The term $\mathbf{F}$ relates diffusive fluxes to gradients in the unknown $u$. The advective flux that results from having gradients along the direction of transport (given by the velocity vector field $\mathbf{v}$ ) are included in the $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ term.

The term $\dot{\mathbf{f}}$ involves upstream sampling to find the value $u^{ * }$ which represents the value of $u$ at the beginning of the timestep. This is achieved using a swarmVariable that carries history information along the flow path. A dense sampling is required to achieve similar accuracy to the original SLCN approach but it allows the use of a single swarm for history tracking of variables with different interpolation order and for material tracking. The user is required to supply and update the swarmVariable representing $u^{ * }$

Properties

  • The unknown is $u$.

  • The velocity field is $\mathbf{v}$ and is provided as a sympy function to allow operations such as time-averaging to be calculated in situ (e.g. V_Field = v_solution.sym)

  • The history variable is $u^*$ and is provided in the form of a sympy function. It is the user's responsibility to keep this variable updated.

  • The diffusivity tensor, $\kappa$ is provided by setting the constitutive_model property to one of the scalar uw.constitutive_models classes and populating the parameters. It is usually a constant or a function of position / time and may also be non-linear or anisotropic.

  • Volumetric sources of $u$ are specified using the $f$ property and can be any valid combination of sympy functions of position and meshVariable or swarmVariable types.

Notes

  • The solver requires relatively high order shape functions to accurately interpolate the history terms. Spiegelman & Katz recommend cubic or higher degree for $u$ but this is not checked.

Reference

Spiegelman, M., & Katz, R. F. (2006). A semi-Lagrangian Crank-Nicolson algorithm for the numerical solution of advection-diffusion problems. Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems, 7(4). https://doi.org/10.1029/2005GC001073

def navier_stokes_problem_description(self): 
2419    def navier_stokes_problem_description(self):
2420        # f0 residual term
2421
2422        self._u_f0 = (
2423            self.F0 - self.bodyforce + self.rho * self.DuDt.bdf() / self.delta_t
2424        )
2425
2426        # f1 residual term
2427        self._u_f1 = (
2428            self.F1
2429            + self.DFDt.adams_moulton_flux()
2430            - sympy.eye(self.mesh.dim) * (self.p.sym[0])
2431        )
2432        self._p_f0 = sympy.simplify(self.PF0 + sympy.Matrix((self.constraints)))
2433
2434        return

def solve( self, zero_init_guess: bool = True, timestep: float = None, _force_setup: bool = False, verbose=False, evalf=False, order=None): 
2527    @timing.routine_timer_decorator
2528    def solve(
2529        self,
2530        zero_init_guess: bool = True,
2531        timestep: float = None,
2532        _force_setup: bool = False,
2533        verbose=False,
2534        evalf=False,
2535        order=None,
2536    ):
2537        """
2538        Generates solution to constructed system.
2539
2540        Params
2541        ------
2542        zero_init_guess:
2543            If `True`, a zero initial guess will be used for the
2544            system solution. Otherwise, the current values of `self.u` will be used.
2545        """
2546
2547        if order is None or order > self._order:
2548            order = self._order
2549
2550        if timestep is not None and timestep != self.delta_t:
2551            self.delta_t = timestep  # this will force an initialisation because the functions need to be updated
2552
2553        if _force_setup:
2554            self.is_setup = False
2555
2556        if not self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup:
2557            self.is_setup = False
2558            self.DFDt.psi_fn = self.constitutive_model.flux.T
2559
2560        if not self.is_setup:
2561            self._setup_pointwise_functions(verbose)
2562            self._setup_discretisation(verbose)
2563            self._setup_solver(verbose)
2564
2565        if uw.mpi.rank == 0 and verbose:
2566            print(f"NS solver - pre-solve DuDt update", flush=True)
2567
2568        # Update SemiLagrange Flux terms
2569        self.DuDt.update_pre_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=evalf)
2570        self.DFDt.update_pre_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=evalf)
2571
2572        if uw.mpi.rank == 0 and verbose:
2573            print(f"NS solver - solve Stokes flow", flush=True)
2574
2575        super().solve(
2576            zero_init_guess,
2577            _force_setup=_force_setup,
2578            verbose=verbose,
2579            picard=0,
2580        )
2581
2582        if uw.mpi.rank == 0 and verbose:
2583            print(f"NS solver - post-solve DuDt update", flush=True)
2584
2585        self.DuDt.update_post_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=evalf)
2586        self.DFDt.update_post_solve(timestep, verbose=verbose, evalf=evalf)
2587
2588        self.is_setup = True
2589        self.constitutive_model._solver_is_setup = True
2590
2591        return

Generates solution to constructed system.

Params

zero_init_guess: If True, a zero initial guess will be used for the system solution. Otherwise, the current values of self.u will be used.
